column1: ---split---2.0---split---https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/16/opinion/esquire-american-boy-cancel-culture.html---split---Supported by I’m a trans woman living in Brooklyn. And I have tremendous empathy for the conservative teen in Wisconsin. By Robyn Kanner Ms. Kanner is a writer and designer living in Brooklyn. I have an embarrassing secret. One I have long feared the internet would out for me. So allow me to out myself: In 2004
column2: I campaigned for George W. Bush. To see me now — a trans woman living in Brooklyn
column3: with “Infinite Jest” on my nightstand and “This Is America” on repeat — it’s hard to imagine me campaigning for Mr. Bush and Dick Cheney. But growing up
column4: it could not have been a more natural choice. I grew up in Fairfield
column5: Maine. My hometown has a population of 6
column6: 563. It is 97.5 percent white. I drank coffee out of plastic foam cups before school
column7: and in the summer all the teens in my neighborhood would meet down at the Kennebec River and go fishing
column8: even though the river was too polluted for us to eat what we caught. In a town that tiny you don’t pick your friends based on interests. It’s about who’s around. So when a fervent conservative friend asked if I wanted to campaign for Bush after cross-country practice I said of course. Standing on the sidewalk at the only intersection with a red light
column9: we divvied up our signs and began to shout. “Bush for President! He’ll keep us safe!” I may have lacked a nuanced worldview
column10: but I knew 9/11 wasn’t good. A man in a truck honked his horn in support. A woman rolled down her window and shouted: “No more war! Bring our troops home!” I was a naïve kid
column11: happy to hang out with a friend. Fifteen years later
column12: my views have changed dramatically. I voted for Barack Obama in 2008 and 2012
column13: and for Hillary Clinton in 2016. I believe that every person in America deserves health care. I don’t think we’re paying enough attention to the destructive damages of addiction. I’m terrified of climate change and believe we should end the use of fossil fuels. All my friends are gay. Still
column14: I harbor an intense fear that part of my past will be used to invalidate the person I am now. I’m afraid of what my friends would think of my campaigning for Mr. Bush. Would I lose their trust? Would they fear that I secretly support war or xenophobic views? Would they believe me if I told them that campaigning for Mr. Bush was one impolitic moment on a long journey of understanding who I am? Things are far worse for Americans younger than me — those who don’t know a world without the internet. The one on my mind this week is Ryan Morgan
column15: a 17-year-old from West Bend
column16: Wis. He’s the cover boy of the latest issue of Esquire — the subject of a story called “An American Boy” by Jennifer Percy. Morgan is a white
column17: middle-class teenager growing up in a conservative home with parents who support President Trump. He’s a sneakerhead who loves video games and the Green Bay Packers. He hates how politics are dividing his friendships. “Last year was really bad.” he tells Esquire. “I couldn’t say anything without pissing someone off.” In Wisconsin
column18: white people account for 87.3 percent of the population. In the 2016 election
column19: President Trump took all of the state’s 10 electoral votes. Ryan Morgan may not be the American boy some want
column20: but he is the American boy who is. Still
column21: his presence in Esquire sparked rage online. Zara Rahim
column22: a spokeswoman for Clinton’s 2016 campaign
column23: called out Esquire for running the story during Black History Month. “Imagine this same ‘American Boy’ headline with someone who looks like Trayvon talking about what it’s like to have your mother sit you down to tell you how to stay alive
column24: ” she wrote on Twitter. Others echoed the complaint. One can debate whether the article should have run a month earlier or later
column25: or whether Esquire runs enough stories about teenage boys of color. But few if any of those criticisms actually engaged with the story itself: Was the portrait wrong? Did it add value to our understanding of America in this moment? While many in the press attacked Esquire
column26: others went for Ryan Morgan. Some suggested he needed to be punched. Some suggested sending him hate mail. Others just swore. If in 2020
column27: he chooses to go to college
column28: the Esquire story and the reaction to it will come up during his interview. If in 2025 he finds himself online dating
column29: it will be right there
column30: on Google
column31: for any potential dates to find. People change
column32: pictures don’t. Katie Herzog is a gay journalist who knows exactly what it feels like to wear a digital scarlet letter. In 2017 she wrote an article called “The Detransitioners” for the independent Seattle newspaper The Stranger. In the piece
column33: she reports on people who’ve transitioned to a different gender and then transitioned back. The piece was met with visceral hatred. Ms. Herzog received hate mail
column34: including videos of people lighting her article on fire. I was part of the pile on. In a now deleted tweet
column35: I called her “trash.” I feared that her piece somehow discredited my own identity. In fact
column36: it was just adding nuance to a debate in queer culture. She agreed to get on a call with me after I apologized. “I don’t go to queer spaces anymore
column37: ” she told me. “My ex-girlfriend publicly called me out
column38: and then when I saw her in public she just turned her back on me.” The reaction shook her. Everything in her life has changed since that article. “If I go out and order food
column39: I’ll lie about my name.” And Katie Herzog is an adult with strong views about the world. Like myself at 17
column40: the teenager on Esquire’s cover clearly doesn’t have strong political values or ideas; he seems to have adopted those of the people around him
column41: maybe simply because he wants to fit in. Indeed
column42: he talks about softening his positions to avoid being ostracized: “It’s better to be a moderate
column43: because then you don’t get heat.” He is currently being shamed for being uninformed
column44: for being a normal teenager. Digital shaming is arguably the only punishment that does not have a statute of limitations. Do we really want to live in a culture like this? Where no one has the room to grow or change or become a new version of him or herself? I’d like to think that the differences between me in 2019 and me in 2004 is a sign that we all can. The question is whether we can give one another the generosity to do so. Ms. Kanner (@robynkanner) is a writer and designer living in Brooklyn. The Times is committed to publishing a diversity of letters to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some tips. And here’s our email: letters@nytimes.com. Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook
column45: Twitter (@NYTopinion) and Instagram. An earlier version of the caption accompanying this article misstated the date for the issue of Esquire shown. It is the March issue of the magazine
column46: not February. Advertisement

column1: ---split---2.0---split---https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/14/magazine/north-korea-black-market-economy.html---split---Feature Far from the stereotype of total economic isolation
column2: the black market has brought a surprising degree of modernity and consumerism — for some. CreditCreditIllustration by Sally Deng Supported by By Travis Jeppesen One Night in Pyongyang
column3: around 9 p.m.
column4: my North Korean minder
column5: S.
column6: and I pulled into the empty parking lot of the Chongryu Restaurant on the quiet banks of the Potong River. It was the spring of 2017
column7: and
column8: though I didn’t know it at the time
column9: I was among the last Americans to visit North Korea before a travel ban took effect. It was my fifth trip in five years to the country
column10: whose supposed impenetrability to American visitors had spurred me to visit as often as possible. On my first three visits
column11: I traveled as an ordinary tourist
column12: which was surprisingly easy to do (albeit in a highly monitored
column13: regimented fashion); then
column14: in the summer of 2016
column15: I enrolled in a monthlong immersive Korean-language program at Kim Hyong-jik University of Education. Now I was back in the country to take an additional two weeks of language classes by day while covertly making further notes for a book in my hotel room at night. This was the second time that S.
column16: who was 26
column17: had been assigned to look after me in less than a year; she had become something like a friend. Over the course of my visits
column18: I learned that young couples often met for night strolls along this stretch of the Potong. “Are we here for a date?” I joked. S. laughed. “Yeah
column19: sure
column20: ” she said. “We have a date tonight with Comrade K.!” K. — I refer to several key people in this article by their first initials to protect them and their relatives from reprisal — was the director of the state-owned travel company that arranged my visit. He had offered to take me out for a drink at his favorite gastro pub
column21: in east Pyongyang near the Juche Tower
column22: a 560-foot candle with a cherry-red flame kept constantly lit throughout the night. (The tower was built in 1982 on the orders of Kim Jong-il as a 70th-birthday present to his father
column23: the North Korean founding leader Kim Il-sung.) In Pyongyang
column24: a city that requires drivers to hold a special permit to be out past 11
column25: 9 p.m. felt decidedly late. We climbed out of the car to take in the late spring nocturne. In addition to S. and I
column26: there was our required second guide
column27: P.
column28: as well as our driver. Usually
column29: the tour guides are tasked with looking after large groups
column30: but with all the bad publicity — North Korea’s relations with the West were at their worst
column31: with missile launches and the imprisonment of an American college student named Otto Warmbier (who would later die after falling into a coma during his 17 months in North Korean custody) dominating the news cycle — tourism numbers
column32: already low
column33: had been plummeting. For the next two weeks
column34: I would be the sole foreigner in their charge. Across the otherwise vacant parking lot
column35: about a dozen figures were shuttling between the back of an open truck and the river
column36: removing what appeared to be solar panels and carrying them to float upon the placid waters. I had begun to notice solar panels on apartment balconies throughout the city — a convenient solution to the country’s electricity shortages for those who can afford it — and knew that placing them in water was a way to cool them off. But owing to the great quantity here
column37: it almost seemed as if the panels were being set afloat as a form of display
column38: as if they were merchandise for sale. As I wondered what exactly it was I was seeing
column39: P. shrieked out to her fellow Koreans: “Jangmadang! Jangmadang!” “Jangmadang! Jangmadang!” I echoed playfully. My minders ceased their laughter and looked down at the ground. They had forgotten for a moment that I was a language student; jangmadang was one word I was not supposed to know. Usually translated as “market grounds
column40: ” jangmadang is the word for the unofficial markets that emerged during the Arduous March
column41: which is the regime’s official name for the famine that blighted the country throughout the middle and late 1990s. These were illegal markets
column42: to begin with
column43: that sprang up as a result of the collapse of the public food-distribution system that all North Koreans had previously relied on for their monthly rations. During the later years of Kim Jong-il’s reign
column44: the government began to grudgingly accept their existence and took steps toward regulating them: charging rent for stalls
column45: controlling prices and monitoring what goods were for sale. Under Kim Jong-un
column46: the restrictions against this form of private enterprise have been all but lifted
column47: and jangmadang has transcended the cramped market stalls of its birth to refer to the vast array of legal
column48: illegal and semi-legal markets that exist for all sorts of goods in North Korea. Among recent defectors and expat residents
column49: it is said that now
column50: as long as you have money
column51: you can buy anything you want in North Korea. But since the government still hasn’t figured out a way of publicly reconciling with this nascent form of capitalism
column52: it was considered taboo to discuss the jangmadang with foreigners. Which is a shame
column53: because the rise of the jangmadang is arguably the most significant milestone in North Korea’s recent history. It lies at the root of all the country’s economic development over the past few years. They might not be permitted to speak about it with outsiders
column54: but North Koreans are no longer shy about flaunting their consumption habits
column55: as anyone who has witnessed the displays on the streets of Pyongyang in recent years can attest. Montblanc watches
column56: Ray-Ban sunglasses and Burberry couture hardly fit the stereotype of a half-starved populace completely cut off from the outside world. And while extreme poverty continues to afflict large swaths of the population
column57: North Korean society no longer conforms to a simplistic picture of haves and have-nots
column58: but is home to an increasingly diverse and complex array of socioeconomic classes. While the presence of a rising upper middle class is most apparent in Pyongyang
column59: a nouveau riche strata has been observed in other parts of the country
column60: such as the port city of Chongjin and in many places along the border with China
column61: where licit and illicit trade continues to flourish. Stewing in awkward silence with my guides
column62: I struggled to reignite the conversation but couldn’t come up with anything witty on the topic of solar panels. I was relieved from this lonely task by the appearance of a figure approaching the parking lot on foot
column63: a 37-year-old man sporting a Dolce & Gabbana flannel shirt and a pair of neon Nikes. Were it not for the red pin bearing the smiling faces of Kims Il-sung and Jong-il installed dutifully over the heart — a pin that all North Korean adults are required to wear in public — he could
column65: easily be mistaken for one of his compatriots from the South. “Comrade K. is here
column66: ” S. announced with a sigh. “Finally.” The Arduous March had many causes
column67: but probably the main one was the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991. During the decades following the Korean War
column68: the Soviets provided North Korea with regime-sustaining aid
column69: such as selling oil at artificially deflated prices in exchange for shoddily made North Korean goods. It made no sense politically
column71: for the Russian Federation to continue this form of aid-as-trade with North Korea. Between 1990 and 1994
column72: annual trade between North Korea and Russia plummeted to $140 million from $2.56 billion
column73: according to one estimate. In the following years
column75: North Korea would experience a devastating famine that killed anywhere from 600
column76: 000 to more than a million people. With food scarce and the government unable to provide through its rationing program
column77: North Koreans began turning away from the official
column78: centrally planned economy. Markets sprang up all over the country
column80: cigarettes and household goods to illegal foreign media. According to Daniel Tudor and James Pearson’s book “North Korea Confidential
column81: ” the stalls were generally operated by middle-aged married women who were compelled to pay a “stall tax” to their local party cadre
column82: “making the state complicit in marketization” — uncomfortably so. In 2009
column84: the government implemented a disastrous currency reform
column85: tried to close down the markets and forbade market activity within the country. This resulted in wide public discontent
column86: and a high-ranking Workers’ Party official was executed as a scapegoat for the government’s decision. Still
column87: the regime had failed in its promise to feed its citizens
column88: and the gray markets of the jangmadang had
column90: filled in the gaps. Today there are more than 400 sanctioned markets in the country
column92: 000 vendors. After the currency reform wiped out the wealth and savings of a number of merchants
column93: the preferred currencies in business became the United States dollar and the Chinese renminbi. According to one survey
column94: some 90 percent of all household expenditures are said to take place in these markets; they are so pervasive that people speak of a Jangmadang Generation that grew up knowing nothing else. Under Kim Jong-un
column95: market activities have not only been tolerated; they have slowly crept into the official sector
column96: as I witnessed firsthand in my visits to the country. Among close observers
column97: there is a growing consensus that the economy has been undergoing a quiet revolution. The South Korean economist Byung-Yeon Kim is among the first to offer hard data about what this transformation looks like
column99: “Unveiling the North Korean Economy.” The average worker in North Korea’s informal economy
column101: earns 80 times more than at an official job. Approximately 23 percent of employees at state-run enterprises are simultaneously involved with some unofficial form of business. At least 58 percent of all companies in North Korea employ so-called 8/3 workers
column102: who pay a fee in order to be absent from work and engage in unofficial market activities; these funds are an important form of revenue for these companies
column103: helping them to continue paying the salaries of their regular employees. This level of systemic corruption gets expensive: From 1996 to 2007
column104: spending on bribes is estimated to have made up between 5.2 and 10.7 percent of total household expenditures. In spite of this endemic corruption
column105: the North Korean economy was growing
column107: at more than 4 percent annually before the latest round of sanctions went into effect in the fall of 2017. “The socialist economic system of North Korea has virtually collapsed
column108: ” Byung-Yeon Kim wrote. [Read more about North Korea’s growing economy in 2017] But this is a shift that has been hard to reconcile with the state’s self-image as a socialist paradise
column109: which it continues to project to the outside world and its own people. Peter Ward
column110: a Seoul National University master’s graduate whose research focuses on the North Korean economy
column111: spent nearly a month traveling in North Korea last summer
column112: perusing official government publications and academic journals. In the course of his research
column113: he discovered that the state had issued new rules
column114: lifting restrictions on the utilization of “order contracts
column115: ” so long as it agrees with the state’s objectives. Order contracts
column116: Ward explained on a recent podcast
column117: involve state-owned enterprises setting their own prices in consultation with customers. They are
column120: but by another name. This change was not confined to any one sector
column122: supply-and-demand economics can be employed by management and staff members of state-owned enterprises in nearly every sector of the economy. At birth
column123: every North Korean citizen is assigned a classification that is kept secret from them. This system is called songbun
column125: there are three main categories — loyal
column126: wavering and hostile — and 51 subcategories that serve as qualifiers. The assignation of songbun is meant to be the chief factor in determining the extent of a citizen’s lifelong opportunity. It is familial
column128: grandparents or great-grandparents were up to during the years of the country’s foundation — or even earlier. Those whose predecessors fought alongside Kim Il-sung in the guerrilla struggles against the Japanese occupiers of Korea before its 1945 liberation are endowed with the highest level of songbun; many of their descendants today occupy the highest echelons in the government. Those branded “hostile” might be the descendants of former landowners or of people who collaborated with the Japanese colonialists
column129: those with relatives in South Korea or Christians; they are largely consigned to the mountainous
column131: forbidden to enter Pyongyang or other major cities and forced to eke out a meager living as farmers or manual toilers
column132: with almost zero opportunity for further advancement. Even if most North Koreans don’t explicitly know what their songbun categorization is
column135: what their ancestors were known to have done
column136: the degree of opportunities open to them and the level of discrimination to which they are regularly subjected from school age onward. Songbun
column137: while a clear component of the police-state apparatus
column138: has historically been tethered to the North’s traditional centrally planned economy. And there is evidence that as North Korea goes further in the direction of the free market
column139: this political class system is eroding. Before my last trip to North Korea in 2017
column140: I spent three months in Seoul interviewing North Korean defectors. One of them
column143: left the country in 2006. Throughout her childhood
column144: which coincided with the famine years
column145: she was able to observe firsthand how the songbun system began to unravel as the country did. It all began
column147: with the death of Kim Il-sung on July 8
column149: with the death of the Great Leader
column150: a catastrophe of such cosmological proportions was inevitable. To Bomhee
column151: a child of 5 at the time
column152: this made perfect sense. People were taken to cry in mass displays of mourning before statues of the leader throughout the country. As if the gods were responding in kind
column153: the skies opened and poured torrential rains across the land
column155: the end of the three-year state-sanctioned mourning period for the eldest Kim
column156: the tone of the propaganda under his son and successor
column158: had shifted to a message of struggle and endurance. In North Korea
column159: salaried wages have always been so low as to be almost meaningless; all essential goods
column161: were meant to be provided by the state’s public rationing system. With Russia’s withdrawal of support
column162: the rations quickly dried up. “My parents told me one day we would no longer be receiving food from the government
column163: ” Bomhee recalls. “We would have to struggle on our own from now on.” Bomhee remembers growing accustomed to the sight of corpses scattered along the ground in her hometown and the mountains
column164: where people would go to forage for anything they could find to eat
column165: including rats and tree bark. When the public distribution system broke down
column166: the starving populace had no choice but to violate the constitution and go into business for themselves. With access to South Korea blocked by the heavily mined Demilitarized Zone
column167: countless northerners fled over the border to China. The border also became a gateway to survival for those who stayed
column168: with traders regularly crossing back and forth with food
column170: as well as more illicit goods such as DVDs
column171: effectively exposing North Koreans to the wider
column172: wealthier world. Bomhee’s family lived close to a gold mine
column173: and the country was corrupt enough by this point that if you knew the right people
column174: you could buy directly from the miners. Her parents got unrefined gold at black-market rates
column176: then sold the pure gold to Chinese investors over the border at the official rate
column177: yielding a profit. Her father eventually started paying his boss a bribe rather than show up for work — with the economy broken
column178: all industry had ground to a halt
column179: so there wasn’t much to do anyway. Bomhee’s mother
column181: began selling homemade food in the jangmadang. Video footage smuggled out of the North reveals these early markets as primitive gatherings on the muddy outskirts of large cities or else down discreet alleyways
column182: merchants squatting or standing above their wares spread over tarps on the ground or gathered in homely sacks that could be readily snatched up should an official arrive. Kotjebi
column183: homeless children whose parents had either died or abandoned them
column184: self-organized into Dickensian gangs. They would stalk the market grounds
column185: pickpocketing choice wares from shoppers’ knapsacks and distracting vendors while their comrades stole food
column186: and they were often severely beaten or even killed in battles with warring gangs. Other lone children
column188: could be seen picking kernels of undigested corn out of piles of animal excrement to eat on the spot. When she was 11
column189: Bomhee would ride her bike after school to a wholesale market and buy 100 pieces of candy for 1
column191: according to today’s unofficial but universally employed exchange rate)
column192: then join her mother in the jangmadang in the deep recesses of the countryside
column193: where she would sell the candy and earn a 10 percent profit. North Korean socialism would never recover from this intrusion of market-based economics. While songbun has never gone away — a severely bad rating is still a huge hurdle to socioeconomic advancement — it is now becoming possible to work out from under it. Another young defector I spoke with
column194: who asked not to be identified
column195: was able to buy a permit required to stay in Pyongyang — certainly not thanks to her parents’ songbun
column196: which was good but not great
column197: but to their money and business connections. She grew up in a city on the Chinese border. Throughout the 2000s
column198: when the border was much more porous than it is today
column199: the markets there were thriving. The defector
column201: dreamed of studying music in the capital. While her mother was doing very well in the markets
column203: 000 bribe that would place her daughter in the country’s top music conservatory. Instead
column204: she negotiated a second-best deal directly with one of the professors
column206: rather than show up for work
column207: had begun teaching the children of elites privately. For a monthly boarding-and-tuition fee
column208: she could live in the professor’s spare room and study piano in Pyongyang. According to a survey conducted by Byung-Yeon Kim among recent defectors
column209: the average monthly salary for a state employee is a little under 2
column211: around 26 cents; people working in the jangmadang
column215: about $21. (To help put those figures in perspective
column216: the current price in Pyongyang for a kilo of rice is 4
column218: or 51 cents.) And while it has traditionally been the case that defectors in the South send money home to their poor relatives still living in North Korea — a situation that mirrors that of Cuban émigrés living in the United States — I have heard from several defectors of a new phenomenon in recent years: wealthy North Koreans sending thousands of dollars each month to their defector children studying in the South. These people belong to the ranks of the upper-middle and upper classes
column219: who aren’t merely selling goods in the jangmadang but conducting trade at globally competitive prices in industries like textiles and seafood. An individual employed in a managerial position at a state-owned company can
column221: engage in practically any profit-making endeavor he or she wants. These activities are “approved” by an official in one of the government ministries
column222: essentially a business partner who takes kickbacks and who in turn pays kickbacks to one of his superiors
column223: in a line that extends all the way up to the ruling family and their associates. Some journalists covering North Korea have compared the regime to a mafia protection racket. As our car crossed the bridge across the wide Taedong River into east Pyongyang
column224: we stopped at a red light in front of a long building with a swerving rooftop. “This is the Ryugyong Health Complex
column225: right?” I asked Comrade K. in the front seat. “Yes
column227: ” he nodded. “But what about the one across the street?” I pointed to a newer building with a shiny blue-mirrored-window facade. “Is that also the Ryugyong? Or does it have a different name?” K. turned around to face me. “You’ve been there?” he asked incredulously. It is not a normal stop on the tours his company operates. In fact
column228: he wasn’t aware that foreigners were allowed to visit. Indeed I had been there
column229: on an earlier visit arranged by one of Comrade K.’s competitors. The amenities of the new health club were impressive. On the ground floor
column230: a shop sold luxury goods: tailored suits
column233: glittering Rolex watches. A snack bar vended an array of imported soft drinks
column234: including a range of Coca-Cola products with Vietnamese packaging. Contrary to the notion spread by some commentators that such sites are merely stage sets to impress foreign visitors
column235: the two dozen customers in the men’s locker room that day appeared genuinely startled by the sudden appearance of me and the other male foreigner in my group who chose to partake of the facilities
column236: which included a traditional Korean jjimjilbang
column238: far more luxurious than any I had chanced to visit in Seoul
column239: and an indoor swimming pool replete with artificial waterfall. K. nodded pensively. “That is ... an extension of the Ryugyong Health Complex.” He chose his words carefully. “But the main building here with the sloping roof and indoor skating rink ... have you been there
column240: as well? That one is for ordinary people.” I had begun to hear this term “ordinary people” with increasing frequency on my last two visits. Usually deployed with a twinge of derogation
column241: it clearly connoted the underclass: the working poor
column243: those not fortunate enough to be employed in an arena that would otherwise be considered gainful and prestigious
column244: that might allow them entry into a place like the one across the street; people lacking the savvy and connections that might help them make it big in the gray-market world of the jangmadang or the managerial gentry of the state-owned enterprises. We pulled into a parking lot. A staircase between a shop selling imported prescription medicines and another offering a mishmash of clothing
column245: furniture and household goods led up to our destination
column247: Taedonggang Beer Bar. It’s all polished wood
column250: bartenders in tuxedos. Were it not for the concert by Moranbong Band being broadcast on the flat-screen television in lieu of a ballgame
column251: I might have imagined myself to be in an upmarket sports bar somewhere in Chicago or Boston. The reasonably robust crowd consisted of North Korean yuppies
column252: their ties and Mao collars loosened after a long day at work. There is a local name for these people: the donju
column253: or money masters. These are certainly not “ordinary” people
column254: though they represent an increasingly sizable segment of the Pyongyang populace
column255: on a tier just below the elites: the nouveau riche. They are not likely to be manning market stalls but collecting rent from them
column256: as well as engaging in other jangmadang economic activity while nominally employed in the official sector: from overseeing the logistics of transporting goods smuggled in from China to running shops and businesses through which such goods might be distributed at a profit. My minders and I commandeered a table while Comrade K. went to the bar to order beers and a kimchi pancake. Though still nominally a tour guide
column257: S. was recently promoted to a managerial position. I asked her what she did all day when there were no tours to lead
column260: was pretty much always. S. smiled coyly and said: “Oh
column262: figure out new ways to kill time. Some of the guys in the office are becoming very skilled at World of Warcraft.” Like most North Koreans I met
column263: she didn’t want to go into too much detail about what she did at work all day
column264: but I had patched together my own hazy picture based on what she let slip on my previous visit to the country
column265: as well as her endlessly buzzing smartphone. S.’s family was far from ordinary. Her father
column267: ” had spent many years living abroad at a North Korean Embassy (as had Comrade K.). Both she and her father made occasional trips abroad to China
column268: Africa and Latin America (as did Comrade K.). Her mother
column271: specializing in European and American cuisines
column272: and offered catering services. At one point
column273: S. asked me flat-out if I knew any businesspeople in Germany
column275: of a riskier disposition who might not totally mind violating sanctions. I asked her what line of business she was interested in pursuing. Off the top of her head
column282: ” she said. After Kim Jong-un inherited the throne in 2011
column283: the central policy of his government was the so-called byungjin line: the simultaneous development of both the economy and the military (i.e. nuclear weapons). This was in many ways a continuation of his father’s military-first policy
column284: which not only increased the size of the country’s standing army but elevated its top brass to a position of unprecedented power. But in April of last year
column285: at the Third Plenary Meeting of the Central Committee of the Workers’ Party
column286: Kim made a startling announcement: The byungjin line was officially dead. The development of nuclear weapons was complete and had been “victorious.” While outsiders continue to debate to what extent Kim intends to denuclearize
column287: it’s notable that his spring announcement was followed by a reshuffling of military personnel at the top
column288: implying a certain discord within the ranks around Kim’s decision
column289: as well as a general downgrading of the military apparatus. Kim went on to declare that the sole focus
column291: would be the development of the economy
column292: while engaging in a diplomatic process to maintain peace and stability on the Korean Peninsula. Besides his brief meeting in Singapore with Donald Trump
column293: Kim has to date met three times for lengthy meetings with the South Korean president
column296: that he believes Kim’s intentions to be sincere. [A guide to Trump and Kim’s next summit meeting.] It is notoriously difficult to know what the regime wants
column297: but between the economic liberalization and the shifts in foreign policy
column298: the upbeat interpretation is that Kim wants to open up North Korea. Bruce Cumings
column299: a professor at the University of Chicago who has written a number of books on modern Korean history
column300: is particularly sunny on the matter. “For the first time in North Korean history
column301: I’m starting to believe that Kim Jong-un is moving in the direction of what Deng Xiaoping did in 1979 in China
column302: ” he told me. “I think his aspiration is create a secure environment in which North Korea can open up to the world economy in the way that China and Vietnam have. That’s very much behind the diplomacy with South Korea that’s been going on since January and the diplomacy with the U.S. I think this has actually been the North Korean goal for the last 25 years
column303: but they found it very difficult to articulate it: some way to bring the U.S. in to solve their strategic problem after the Soviet Union collapsed.” For the economy to grow meaningfully
column304: the North Koreans would need the United States and the United Nations to lift economic sanctions
column305: allowing the country to access goods and
column307: capital. But for this very reason
column308: many are deeply skeptical of Kim’s motives
column309: with hawkish North Korea watchers believing the United States is being suckered into lifting sanctions in exchange for nothing. The question remains whether the monolithic North Korean political system can survive the disruptive force that a market economy poses. The key to the equation might be the donju
column310: who have made themselves an integral part of a complex financial system. Given the paucity of hard data released by North Korea
column311: it is difficult to gauge just how many belong to this rising economic class. One thing is clear
column312: however: Just as Kim has come to rely on the donju
column313: the donju rely on the survival of Kim’s regime. The Russian-born North Korean-studies scholar Andrei Lankov believes that
column314: unlike the upper-middle classes whose discontent with the system played such a pivotal role in the Soviet Union’s downfall
column315: the donju fear that the collapse of the North Korean government and subsequent reunification of the Korean Peninsula would mean having to compete with the global economic behemoths of South Korea
column316: leaving the Northerners with second-class status
column317: or worse. Fully cognizant of the poverty that surrounds them — and the fact that many of them started off as “ordinary” people — it is in their interest that the current status quo be maintained. In this situation
column318: the donju can hardly be thought of as a dissident class; they just want the state to lay off them so that they can get rich. After a round of beers
column319: Comrade K. apologized and said he had to cut the night short. He had to leave the next morning on a business trip to Nampo. Before we all got up to leave
column320: he presented me with a gift: an expensive lighter emblazoned with the Chollima
column321: a winged horse from Asian mythology renowned for its amazing speed of flight. It was invoked by Kim Il-sung in the Chollima Movement of the late 1950s. Similar to the Great Leap Forward in China and the Stakhanovite Movement in the Soviet Union
column322: the Chollima Movement was a mass labor campaign meant to spur rapid economic advancement via “ideological incentives
column323: ” such as Chollima Rider titles bestowed on those who exceeded their quotas. Among other tactics
column324: the government encouraged workers to drink less soup so as to take fewer bathroom breaks. The Chollima Movement was lauded as a historical milestone in North Korea
column325: but some outside observers have claimed that it resulted in little more than an exhausted
column326: undernourished populace and an array of shoddy
column327: inferior products and that it was yet another example of the government’s legacy of economic ineptitude. K. also handed me a green carton of cigarettes. “This is the new trend brand here in Pyongyang
column330: lowering his voice: “The brand that the elites smoke.” I read the name of the company that makes them aloud: “Naegohyang.” My hometown. At the cash register
column332: but Comrade K. waved his hand
column333: removed a thick wad of $50 bills from the breast pocket of his Dolce & Gabbana shirt
column334: peeled one off and slapped it down. The hostess’s fingers danced across her pocket calculator
column335: and she returned his change in a combination of dollars and a few thousand worth of won notes featuring Kim Il-sung’s smiling face. With a scowl
column337: slid the won across the table back to the hostess and sauntered out to the parking lot
column338: where our driver was waiting. Travis Jeppesen is a writer whose most recent book is “See You Again in Pyongyang.” This is his first article for the magazine.   Advertisement

column2: D-Texas

column4: he would tear down the border fence separating his hometown of El Paso
column5: Texas
column6: from Mexico. (Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call file photo) Potential 2020 presidential candidate and former Rep. Beto O’Rourke said Thursday that if it were up to him
column7: the border barrier separating his old El Paso
column8: Texas
column9: district from Mexico would come down. “Yes
column10: absolutely. I’d take the wall down
column11: ” the Texas Democrats said in an interview on MSNBC
column12: on the American side of the border wall with a view into Ciudad Juárez
column13: Mexico. In his State of the Union speech
column14: President Donald Trump touted the border barrier in El Paso for making the city safer. “Walls work
column15: ” the president claimed
column16: invoking El Paso
column17: though he did not cite any statistics to support his theory that the barrier in El Paso had an impact on crime rates. Crime rates in El Paso since 1985 have been well below the national average for large American cities
column18: FBI statistics show. The violent crime rate in the Texas border city has been steadily decreasing since the early 1990s
column19: with no discernible difference in the rate dropping since the 57-mile border fence went up in 2008. In fact
column20: violent crime slightly increased between 2007 and 2010 but has mostly been on the decline since
column21: statistics show. Watch: Trump and Beto O’Rourke strike contrasting messages in dueling Texas rallies O’Rourke said that crossings at the southern border with Mexico become a hot political issue for the wrong reasons when people feel national and homeland security threats. Since the 9/11 attacks
column22: politicians have fanned those fears with measures to turbocharge border security
column23: O’Rourke suggested. “We do this
column24: whether it is the war on terror
column25: the war on drugs — we project our fears and anxieties to places like El Paso
column26: to the U.S.-Mexico border
column27: and punish the people who live here
column28: ” O’Rourke said. “There’s no reason to do that. But it is the fear and the anxiety that is stoked by people who should and frankly do know better that results in these policies

column1: ---split---3.0---split---http://www.rollcall.com/news/congress/republicans-have-concerns-about-trumps-executive-action-too---split---Sen. Lamar Alexander
column2: R-Tenn.
column3: said in a statement Friday that the president's national emergency declaration defies the Founders. (Photo By Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call) Some in the president’s party are wringing their hands about how the emergency declaration for a border wall might set a reckless precedent. While Congressional Republicans have raised concerns
column4: most held off on denouncing the president’s radical maneuver to circumvent Article I of the Constitution and devote federal funds to a border wall without their approval. They wonder how a future Democratic president could circumvent Congress on liberal spending priorities like the Green New Deal — the sprawling plan supported by Democratic progressives to address climate change by restructuring the economy and phasing out fossil fuels. Among the most stinging criticisms came from Sen. Lamar Alexander
column5: chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee that oversees the budget for the Army Corps of Engineers. The Tennessee Republican said Trump's national emergency declaration is
column6: "is inconsistent with the U.S. Constitution" and the congressional power of the purse. In a statement
column7: Alexander also called the declaration both "unnecessary" and "unwise." “It is unwise because if this president can declare a national emergency to build a wall
column8: the next president can declare a national emergency to tear it down; or declare a climate change emergency to close coal plants and build wind turbines; or a health care emergency and force into Medicare the 180 million Americans with health insurance on the job
column9: Alexander said. “It is inconsistent with the U.S. Constitution because, after the American Revolution against a king, our founders chose not to create a chief executive with the power to tax the people and spend their money any way he chooses, said Alexander
column10: the Energy-Water chairman. "The Constitution gives that authority exclusively to a Congress elected by the people.” Rep. Cathy McMorris Rodgers
column11: R-Wash.
column12: former Republican conference chair
column13: said the declaration could subvert the balance of powers between branches of government. She said she worries it could open the door to passing a Green New Deal by fiat. “If elected president
column14: how would Elizabeth Warren or Bernie Sanders use this precedent for a national disaster declaration to force the Green New Deal on the American people?” McMorris Rodgers said in a statement. Sen. Marco Rubio
column15: R-Fla.
column16: echoed that concern. “Today’s national emergency is border security. But a future president may use this exact same tactic to impose the Green New Deal
column17: ” Rubio said in a statement. Rubio did not say whether he supported or opposed an emergency declaration
column18: but instead said he would “wait to see what statutory or constitutional power the President relies on to justify such a declaration.” Sen. Chuck Grassley
column19: R-Iowa
column20: also held off on staking a position on the national emergency declaration
column21: but underscored his support for the president’s wall push. “The Constitution grants Congress the authority to appropriate federal dollars
column22: so I’m sure such action will be litigated in the courts
column23: ” Grassley said in a statement. “What’s clear
column24: however
column25: is that the president takes the situation at our border seriously and that Democrats do not.” White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders announced in a Thursday statement that the president will sign a budget deal to avert a government shutdown. In the same statement
column26: she announced the president would “take other executive action — including a national emergency.” According to White House aides
column27: a national emergency declaration would grant Trump broad authority to redirect money appropriated to the Pentagon and U.S. Treasury in order to construct a border wall. Sen. Susan Collins
column28: R-Maine
column29: said she was concerned about how an emergency declaration would weaken the power of Congress to appropriate federal funds. It “strikes me as undermining the appropriations process
column30: the will of Congress and of being of dubious constitutionality
column31: ” Collins said in an interview with USA Today. Here are some of the other Republicans who have raised concerns about an emergency declaration for a border wall: Rep. Chris Stewart Rep. Chris Stewart
column32: R-Utah
column33: said a Democratic president could deem climate change or gun violence a national emergency in order to outmaneuver Congress on appropriating tax dollars. “Whether the president has the authority or not
column34: it sets a dangerous precedent and places America on a path that we will regret
column35: ” he said. “It deeply worries me that a future Democratic president may consider gun violence or climate change a ‘national emergency’ and what actions they may then take.” Sen. Mitt Romney Sen. Mitt Romney
column36: R-Utah
column37: supported the budget deal but said an emergency declaration is not the “right approach.” I'll reserve judgment on any potential executive action by the President until I'm able to fully evaluate it
column38: but as I’ve said
column39: I don't believe declaring a national emergency is the right approach. I'd also expect the President to stay within statutory and constitutional limits.  Sen. Rand Paul Sen. Rand Paul
column40: R-Ky.
column41: supports a border wall
column42: but the libertarian senator said he opposes the emergency declaration
column43: which he described as “extraconstitutional.” “I
column44: too
column45: want stronger border security
column46: including a wall in some areas. But how we do things matters. Over 1
column47: 000 pages dropped in the middle of the night and extraconstitutional executive actions are wrong
column48: no matter which party does them
column49: ” Paul said. Rep. Will Hurd The Texas congressman and only Republican to represent a district along the southern border
column50: said in an appearance on The View that about “1
column51: 000 landowners are going to be impacted. And guess what? They're going to sue.” Rep. Will Hurd on how landowners in his district along the border will react to the wall: "They're going to sue because in the great state of Texas
column52: we care about a little thing called 'private property rights.'" https://t.co/f8u2wc159S pic.twitter.com/5811OdClp4  Rep. Mike Turner “I supported this funding deal as a step towards securing our border
column53: which we absolutely must do. However
column54: I believe it is a dangerous precedent for the President to be forced to declare a national emergency because Congress refuses to provide necessary funding to protect our country
column55: the Ohio Republican said in a statement. As I have voiced to this Administration repeatedly
column56: I strongly believe securing our border should not be done at the expense of previously funded military construction projects.” Sen. Mike Lee The Utah Republican
column57: who supports an originalist view of the U.S. Constitution
column58: issued a gentle criticism of the president's Article I workaround on Twitter Friday afternoon. "My initial assessment is that what Pres. Trump announced is legal. Whether or not it should be legal is a different matter
column59: Lee said. Congress has been ceding far too much power to the exec. branch for decades. We should use this moment as an opportunity to start taking that power back." column1: ---split---3.0---split---http://www.rollcall.com/news/opinion/they-think-northam-should-get-another-chance-its-complicated---split---Virginia Governor Ralph Northam has been doing a lot of learning this month — about blackface
column2: apologies and redemption. African-Americans who believe he should stay in his post are used to making political compromises to survive
column3: Curtis writes. (Alex Edelman/Getty Images) OPINION — The lessons of this February’s Black History Month commemorations have already veered far beyond the usual ones that begin and end by quoting a snippet of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech — the part about judging folks not by the color of their skin but by the content of their character. A new curriculum is being written in real time
column4: affecting real-life politicians and their constituents. And Virginia is hardly the only state not ready for the big exam. Of course
column5: the politician in question
column6: Gov. Ralph Northam
column7: has been learning as he goes — about blackface
column8: about apologies and about redemption. It is no surprise that those most qualified to teach forgiveness have been the African-American citizens of his state. They have had lots of practice since the first enslaved people were brought to Virginia 400 years ago. A Washington Post poll shows that most believe he should stay in his post and do the job he was elected to do. Part of that may be “better the devil you know.” But it is also clear in several stories published about his own history that the motivation of those who think Northam has made the right decision in choosing not to exit quietly is more complicated than that. Friends of every race who have known Northam since he grew up on Virginia’s Eastern shore paint the picture of a man who was a good
column9: fair and friendly classmate in a high school that changed from white to majority black after desegregation was finally implemented years and lawsuits after 1954’s Brown v. Board of Education. That decision led to massive official resistance to integration. Virginia closed its public schools rather than comply
column10: leaving white students to enter segregated academies and black student to fend for themselves. Also watch: Trump calls on Rep. Ilhan Omar to resign The personal and public kindnesses of Northam through high school and then college at Virginia Military Institute stood out for many who spoke with reporters. They are saddened by the caricature that has spawned outrage and Saturday Night Live skits. Reverend King also once said
column11: “It is appalling that the most segregated hour of Christian America is 11 o’clock on Sunday morning.” Though that still holds true in many communities
column12: Northam and his wife attend a church congregation with mostly black worshippers
column13: led by a black pastor. That’s not saying the embattled governor deserves a medal for acting like a human being. It is understandable that some of those voters who supported him feel betrayed. When Northam said he did not become aware until a few years ago of the pain of blackface — and when Attorney General Mark Herring confessed to his own moment imitating rap artists all too authentically — it was difficult to believe that they reached adulthood that clueless. But then it wasn’t. Teachers
column14: schools and parents are still letting children of all races down when they skip over inconvenient history
column15: when textbooks call enslaved people “workers
column16: ” “immigrants” and “indentured servants
column17: ” as Northam himself did on CBS and was quickly corrected by Gayle King. The morning anchor
column18: who is African-American
column19: would not have ascended to her prestigious job with so many blank spaces where knowledge should be. But it is still possible for white Americans to become a governor or attorney general or a CEO and have no idea about African-Americans
column20: Hispanic Americans
column21: Asian-Americans and Native Americans
column22: their histories
column23: contributions and struggles
column24: and the advantage that gave white citizens. It helps explain the inequities in wealth
column25: housing
column26: education and job opportunities whose effects persist long after slavery and Jim Crow. There is a reason some die-hard Cleveland Indians fans cling to the grinning Chief Wahoo and Covington Catholic school boys and their teachers thought war whoops and tomahawk chops were harmless fun. Which brings me
column27: and all of us
column28: to the president of the United States and Republican politicians in Virginia and beyond
column29: who are enjoying the spectacle — popcorn in hand — of Democrats imploding in a state that had been trending blue. While Northam
column30: however clumsily
column31: is calling for learning and healing
column32: the GOP looks eager to shut it and the governor down. It’s not that they are champions of liberty
column33: justice and equal opportunity for all. In fact
column34: when Donald Trump
column35: looking to take advantage
column36: took to Twitter to sow racial division by exploiting the scandals — and to compare the Democratic Party’s treatment of Northam
column37: Herring and Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax
column38: who has denied sexual assault charges by two women — Twitter roared back
column39: reminding the president of his own road to the White House
column40: paved with birtherism and racist insults. There is plenty of evidence
column41: from housing discrimination lawsuits that padded the Trump fortune
column42: to administration policy that separated parents from children and then lost track of them
column43: to a recent possible reference to the Trail of Tears to score points on an opponent (and the current president’s worship of that policy’s father
column44: President Andrew Jackson
column45: for whom the removal of Native Americans from their land was a priority). Republicans may pull Iowa Rep. Steve King from committees as payment for his vocal support of white nationalist ideals
column46: but the congressman remains in his U.S. House seat. The African-Americans who want to give Northam another chance are used to the compromise needed to survive. In this case
column47: a governor who champions voting rights and Medicaid expansion looks pretty good compared with a GOP moving in the other direction. And most Virginians of any race realize that Republicans
column48: like Virginia Senate Majority Leader Tommy Norment
column49: managing editor of a 1968 VMI yearbook sprinkled with blackface photos and racist slurs
column50: have less than pristine racial pasts. Every February
column51: someone asks why we need a Black History Month. And every February
column52: and the rest of the year
column53: comes the proof of the price each American pays for playing politics instead of putting aside the inconvenient conversations that may cause pain
column54: but ultimately will keep the country from making the same costly mistakes over and over again. Mary C. Curtis has worked at The New York Times
column55: The Baltimore Sun
column56: The Charlotte Observer and as national correspondent for Politics Daily. Follow her on Twitter @mcurtisnc3. Get breaking news alerts and more from Roll Call on your iPhone or your Android. column1: ---split---3.0---split---https://www.wired.com/story/italy-five-star-movement-techno-utopians/---split---On the night of Italy’s 2013 parliamentary elections
column2: Paola Nugnes decided to stay late at her office and catch up on work. She skipped the rolling election coverage on TV. And by the time she finally left her architecture studio to go out
column3: it was well past dark. When she arrived at Mumble Rumble
column4: a nightclub in western Naples
column5: at around 9 pm
column6: Nugnes still hadn’t checked the news. The club was hosting a party for activists in a political movement Nugnes had been part of for the past six years. And as she walked in
column7: the crowd erupted. Nugnes asked if her friend Roberto Fico
column8: the most famous local figure in the group
column9: had won his race for a seat in Parliament. But before anyone could answer
column10: a pack of journalists pounced
column11: thrusting microphones in her face: “How do you feel about being elected?” Nugnes stared at them
column12: dumbfounded. That’s how she found out she was now a senator. Along with hundreds of other political rookies
column13: Nugnes had run for office under the banner of something called Five Star
column14: an online phenomenon whose explosive
column15: organic rise was shocking even to those it had just swept into power. Just a few years before
column16: in the mid-2000s
column17: the movement had been little more than the fan base of a blog fronted by a foulmouthed comedian
column18: Beppe Grillo; from there it became an earnest protest movement organized around Meetup.com groups called Friends of Grillo; then it had unified under the name Five Star in 2009. The movement tapped deeply into one of the most powerful forces in Italian politics: disgust with Italian politics. Rather than offer an ideology or platform
column19: Five Star offered a wholesale rebuke of the country’s entrenched
column20: highly paid
column21: careerist political class—left
column22: right
column23: and center. And it married that disdain to a grand techno-utopian project: Through an online voting and debate portal
column24: Five Star was building a direct democracy on the internet. The long-term goal was to replace Parliament altogether—to automate it out of existence. But in the meantime
column25: Five Star had also decided to displace the establishment seat by seat. How Trump Could Wind up Making Globalism Great Again The Political Education of Silicon Valley Why Tech Worker Dissent Is Going Viral The 2013 election was Five Star’s first foray into national politics. While a handful of its candidates were expected to win their races
column26: Nugnes highly doubted she would be one of them; she barely gave it a thought
column27: in fact. So Nugnes had worked through the evening
column28: while the rest of the country reeled from the news that Five Star was now Italy’s second-biggest party
column29: having swept 25 percent of the vote
column30: upending the political establishment in a single stroke. Amid the whirl of embraces and congratulations at the election night party
column31: Nugnes struggled to think through the ramifications. “We were all very excited—and frightened
column32: ” she says. She would have to quit her architecture studio. “It was very traumatic
column33: ” she says. A couple hours’ drive up the coast
column34: near Rome
column35: Elena Fattori
column36: a molecular biologist who was also active in Five Star
column37: faced a similar bout of disbelief that night. “I had taken it all very lightly
column38: ” she says of her run for the senate—so much so that she volunteered to help supervise the vote count that day. As she watched the running tally
column39: Fattori could see firsthand that Five Star was far exceeding expectations and
column40: eventually
column41: that she herself had been elected. “It was a shock
column42: ” Fattori tells me. “I took a couple of days to accept it.” All told
column43: some 160 Five Star candidates with virtually no experience in politics became members of Parliament that day. This put the movement in an awkward position. Governments in Italy are normally formed via alliances between two or more parties that can command a majority of seats in Parliament; Five Star had won so many seats that it had the option of going straight into a governing coalition with the first-placed bloc
column44: led by the center-left Democratic Party. But that was out of the question: One of Five Star’s founding principles was “no alliances.” And besides
column45: the movement saw the Democratic Party as central to the corrupt establishment it had sworn to fight. So Five Star went into opposition. While Five Star sees itself as neither right- nor left-wing
column46: much of the party’s base is left-leaning. Many of its voters and activists
column47: including Fattori and Nugnes
column48: were drawn to the movement after becoming disenchanted with the Democrats and other parties on the left. Nugnes
column49: a woman with Marxist sympathies
column50: had grown alienated from Italy’s communist parties
column51: which she viewed as ailing
column52: top-down institutions. “I felt like an orphan
column53: ” she recalls. Five Star
column54: by contrast
column55: was a “cultural revolution
column56: ” a horizontal movement that put governing directly in the hands of anyone who cared to log on. To the extent that Five Star did have a political platform
column57: it vaguely resembled that of a Green Party. The movement’s name ostensibly refers to its first five policy priorities: sustainable transportation
column58: sustainable development
column59: public water
column61: and environmentalism. Nugnes was particularly attracted to the movement’s more recent flagship policy
column62: a universal basic income that proposed a monthly stipend of 780 euros (a bit less than $900) for Italy’s poorest citizens. In short: While the movement had always included people across the political spectrum
column63: it was easily taken for a progressive popular front. Members of Five Star reeled at where their movement had ended up: tied to a party led by a man many of them regarded as a fascist. But if Nugnes and Fattori were shocked to become elected members of government
column64: the next few years would be even more vertiginous. As the movement’s fledgling nonpoliticians found their feet in Parliament
column65: they realized that dealing with other parties was unavoidable. At times
column66: in opposing the Democratic Party–led government
column67: Five Star found itself siding with another faction defined by antiestablishment roots—a right-wing populist party called Lega
column68: or the League. Lega’s nativist leader
column70: had long campaigned on an “Italians first” platform. He has said that his country needs a “mass cleansing” of illegal immigrants
column73: piazza by piazza.” When Italy’s 2018 national elections came around
column74: Five Star—whose emphasis on popular sovereignty had
column76: come to sound sympatico with anti-EU
column77: anti-immigrant sentiment—won so many seats that it became the largest party in Italy. This time
column78: the movement didn’t shy from stepping up to run the country. And it chose to do so in partnership with Salvini’s Lega. Last September
column80: former chief strategist to Donald Trump and would-be pied piper to Europe’s ethno-nationalists
column81: visited Rome to celebrate the alliance. Of all the countries he had visited in his recent travels
column82: he singled out Italy as “the center of the political universe.” The new government there was a Bannonite dream come true: a left-right
column83: antiestablishment coalition. “A populist party with nationalist tendencies like the Five Stars
column84: and a nationalist party with populist tendencies like the League
column85: ” he enthused to Politico’s European edition. “It’s imperative that this works
column86: because this shows a model for industrial democracies from the US to Asia.” While Bannon gushed
column87: members of Five Star like Nugnes and Fattori reeled at where their movement had ended up: tied to a party led by a man many of them regarded as a fascist. They were also beginning to realize that Five Star’s evolution had never been as organic as it seemed. At every step along the way—from the creation of Grillo’s blog and the organization of the movement’s first mass protests to the construction of its direct-democracy platform
column88: all the way to its recent turn toward nativist politics—Five Star’s course had been meticulously directed by a camera-shy cyber-utopian named Gianroberto Casaleggio
column90: who died of brain cancer in 2016
column93: a familiar type. In the 1990s and early 2000s
column94: he and a slew of other Internet Age prophets—many of them writing in this magazine—foretold a digital revolution that would flatten the priesthoods of politics
column97: and replace them with decentralized webs of direct participation. But Casaleggio
column99: actually went on to mount a revolutionary force that took over a country. Not only that
column100: he directed this supposedly leaderless movement while drawing barely any attention to himself. So here’s the mystery at the heart of Five Star: Who the hell was Gianroberto Casaleggio—and how did he do it? Gianroberto Casaleggio: Cofounder and intellectual father of the movement. Beppe Grillo: The movement’s cofounder and front man. Luigi Di Maio: A Casaleggio protégé
column101: elected the leader of Five Star in 2017. Alessandro Di Battista: Another Casaleggio protégé and one of the movement’s most visible members. Roberto Fico: Unofficial leader of Five Star’s left wing. Paola Nugnes: Left-wing Five Star senator who has been critical of the movement’s rightward turn. The small city of Ivrea sits cradled in the foothills of the Italian Alps
column102: 30 miles south of the Swiss border. An 18th-century bridge over the Dora Baltea river leads to a quaint historic downtown of cobbled streets and pastel-colored buildings. But in the 1970s
column103: Ivrea was Italy’s answer to Silicon Valley. It was the hometown of Olivetti
