column479: Casaleggio published articles on the blog hailing Farage as a democratic crusader against a monolithic EU. “Farage Defends the Sovereignty of the Italian People
column484: such as being an “antiwar … democratic organization” where “no form of racism
column487: ” and which believes in “direct democracy.” The post that finally teed up the online vote made it very clear that the proposed alliance with UKIP was the best and only solution. According to Zanni
column488: this was Casaleggio Associates’ modus operandi when it came to online votes: Provide a “cosmetic” appearance of choice while pushing for a particular option. In the end
column489: 78 percent of the members who voted opted to join Farage. After years of studying how to shape online consensus
column490: Casaleggio had mastered the art. The alliance with UKIP was just the beginning. On a crisp morning in January 2015
column491: Casaleggio Associates received some unusual visitors: Farage
column493: later a Breitbart London editor and aide to Steve Bannon on his European missions—and Liz Bilney
column494: the future CEO of pro-Brexit campaign group Leave.EU. The group wanted to learn how Five Star had pulled off its stunning political rise
column495: and to grasp how it used technology—“to understand the mechanics of it all
column496: ” Bilney says. Casaleggio and his son
column498: gave them a briefing that offered a timeline of important events in web-based politics and the development of Five Star. Then father and son explained the new and improved direct democracy platform they were developing for the movement. Soon
column500: registered members would be able to propose laws and debate and edit them
column501: as well as use the portal to put themselves forward and select candidates in online ballots. As an engine for user engagement—a crucial metric in social media as in politics—the platform seemed formidable. Farage “thought it was fascinating
column503: “because UKIP were keen to build their membership.” Kassam agrees that Farage was “very excited” by the meeting. “He wanted me to go and look into the systems that they used
column505: “and how UKIP might implement them.” The Casaleggios didn’t share much technical know-how with the group
column506: but Kassam was impressed by how many resources they were dedicating to Five Star’s digital operations and data analysis. Bilney
column508: left the meeting buzzing with ideas about the way Five Star used social media. It was this meeting
column510: that “planted the seed of ideas” that would lead to the success of Brexit. Leave.EU was founded six months after the Milan meeting
column511: and a year after that the UK voted to leave the EU. (Bilney is now under criminal investigation for allegedly breaking spending rules.) A few months after the meeting
column512: a post on Grillo’s blog announced that the new version of Five Star’s online direct democracy platform was almost ready. It would be called Rousseau
column513: and it would serve as the Five Star Movement’s mobile-friendly “operating system.” After users logged in
column514: they would land on a homepage with different primary-colored windows for voting on candidates and party decisions
column515: as well as for proposing and debating laws
column517: and more. Beppe Grillo had known that Rousseau—the long-awaited
column519: all-dancing version of the direct democracy web portal—was on its way. What he hadn’t been told was that Casaleggio Associates was also building a new website that would supplant beppegrillo.it as the online home of Five Star. Fearing he was being squeezed out
column520: Grillo confronted Casaleggio. As recounted in the book Supernova
column521: the phone call quickly turned sour: “Vaffanculo!” Casaleggio yelled down the line. “I never want to hear from you again.” “Vaffanculo!  ” Casaleggio yelled down the line. I never want to hear from you again.” Those were the last words Grillo would ever hear from Five Star’s cofounder. Those were the last words Grillo would ever hear from Casaleggio. Grillo initially agreed to a written interview for this article
column524: with a minimum of eight questions. I wondered if it was a weird joke—Grillo is famous for his offbeat humor—but a few days later a post appeared on his blog detailing his new tariff for conversations with the press. WIRED does not pay for interviews. Despite Grillo’s vital role in the rise of Five Star
column527: for the ascension of his son
column529: to a position of great power within the movement. Legal documents signed just before Casaleggio’s death state that Rousseau was to be managed by a new organization
column530: the Rousseau Association. The documents also set up Davide Casaleggio
column531: the new CEO of Casaleggio Associates
column532: to be the Rousseau Association’s president and treasurer. He is
column534: the absolute ruler of Five Star’s data. (Casaleggio declined to speak with WIRED.) Five Star’s MPs are forced by new rules to pay 300 euros a month toward the running of the platform. Grillo
column536: retained the rights to Five Star’s name and logo. On April 12
column538: Gianroberto Casaleggio died in Milan at the age of 61. As his coffin was carried out of the church that houses Leonardo da Vinci’s The Last Supper
column539: a throng of Five Star supporters chanted “Onesta!” (“Honesty!”)—a party slogan. Di Maio and a tearful Di Battista led the chorus. Also in attendance was Umberto Bossi
column540: the founder of Lega. Outside the funeral
column541: a banner read: “We will realize your dream.” The day after Casaleggio died
column542: Rousseau went live. As the 2018 national elections approached
column543: Five Star took one more step away from its original conception as a horizontal
column544: leaderless movement: Via an online ballot on Rousseau
column545: it set about choosing an official party chief. Once again
column546: the contest offered a somewhat cosmetic appearance of choice. Of the best-known
column547: highly groomed members of Five Star
column548: only Luigi Di Maio ran for the job. Fico and Di Battista kept their heads down. So Di Maio was pitted against a slate of relative unknowns
column549: including Elena Fattori. To no one’s surprise
column551: becoming Five Star’s leader at 31 years old in the fall of 2017. Only about 30 percent of Rousseau’s members voted. Afterward
column552: Grillo began to distance himself from the movement. In January 2018
column554: there wasn’t a Five Star logo in sight. Steve Bannon—the former White House chief strategist and far-right impresario—has been trying to unify Europe’s most strident populists into a supergroup called the Movement. Some nationalists have been receptive; others see him as an unwelcome foreign influence. (Go figure.) Five Star has held off on joining. Here’s how Bannon has fared elsewhere. —Graham Hacia BELGIUM - Mischaël Modrikamen: Cofounder of the Belgian People’s Party. Helped establish the Movement. ITALY - Matteo Salvini: Interior minister and leader of the anti-immigrant party Lega. Said his party would join. UK - Jacob Rees-Mogg: Pro-Brexit conservative parliamentarian. Said he has no interest. FRANCE - Marine Le Pen: Leader of France’s far-right National Rally. Met with Bannon but distanced herself. GERMANY - Alice Weidel: Cofounder of the far-right Alternative for Germany party. Called the project “exciting” but then backed away. HUNGARY - Viktor Orbán: Prime minister and leader of the nationalist Fidesz party. Praised the idea but hasn’t committed. SPAIN - Santiago Abascal: Leader of Spain’s ultraconservative VOX party. Said to count his party in. CZECH REPUBLIC - Milos Zeman: President of the Republic. Said “I absolutely disagree with his views.” NETHERLANDS - Geert Wilders: Parliamentary leader of the anti-Islam Party for Freedom. Likes Bannon but hasn’t joined. On March 4
column556: Five Star participated in its second national election. This time
column559: watched the coverage on TV alongside activists and representatives in a hotel in central Naples. Unlike in 2013
column560: everyone knew Five Star would do well. But the final results were nevertheless stunning—with 33 percent of the vote
column561: and after just five years in parliament
column562: Five Star had become the largest party in Italy. While her colleagues celebrated
column563: Nugnes worried. “I just saw right away that the overall picture was very disquieting
column564: ” she says. Right-wing parties—particularly Lega—had performed well too
column565: off the back of a fiercely anti-immigrant campaign. Nugnes watched uneasily as Five Star tried to form a government
column566: seeming to go against the movement’s original “no alliances” principle. From the start
column567: it was clear that Di Maio—who had criticized the previous
column568: centrist government for presiding over a corrupt
column569: NGO-run “sea taxi” service for migrants to Italy—favored a deal with Lega. Nugnes
column570: who had made a name during the previous five years as an outspoken senator
column571: wrote a scathing post on Facebook about the prospect of an alliance with “he who wants to end immigration
column573: Salvini. “I wouldn’t get into the same elevator
column575: “or breathe the same air.” After nearly 90 days of talks
column576: Five Star and Lega came to an agreement; Di Maio and Salvini would share power as deputy prime ministers. When the agreement went up for a vote before Five Star’s members via Rousseau
column577: an astounding 94 percent approved the deal. Movement heavyweights insist that the agreement isn’t an alliance. “If it were an alliance
column580: explaining that the two parties had instead arrived at a “contract” on a specific program of legislation—a contract that included
column582: Five Star’s cherished plan for a universal basic income. The new Italian government was hailed by populists around the world. “What is happening here is extraordinary. There has never been a truly populist government in modern times
column583: ” Bannon told La Repubblica. “I want to be a part of it.” Bannon gloated that he had advised Salvini to make the deal with Five Star
column584: and he claimed that he had advised Five Star as well. A source close to Bannon confirmed to WIRED that when he was in Rome in June
column585: Bannon met with Davide Casaleggio. Days after the new government took power
column586: Salvini—assuming a dual role as both interior minister and deputy PM—closed Italy’s ports to migrant rescue boats and proposed a census of the country’s Roma community ahead of possible expulsions. Some four months later
column587: Five Star’s universal basic income was approved by Parliament in the government’s annual budget. Di Maio promptly took to the balcony of the parliamentary palace to punch the air in celebration. “We’re going to end up with machines replacing many of today’s jobs
column589: echoing a common argument in Silicon Valley. “The basic income can be a tool not just to help struggling families but one that allows us to face the fourth industrial revolution.” “If they expel me
column590: it will mean that this is no longer the right place for me
column592: a left-wing Five Star senator. “There are so many like me in the movement.” The EU has denounced Italy’s universal basic income as profligate. The country’s public debt stands at 2.3 trillion euros
column593: or 130 percent of the country’s GDP
column594: which far exceeds EU limits; authorities in Brussels fear that Italy’s spendthrift budget will cause the country to default on its loans. Salvini quickly seized on Europe’s rejection of the policy to drum up anti-EU support. As his rants against immigration and the EU continue
column595: Lega is soaring past Five Star in opinion polls. Di Maio has done little to push back against the government’s rightward turn
column596: even as the rebels in his party are growing more defiant. Nugnes and Fattori have both courted expulsion from Five Star over the past year
column597: after refusing to vote with the party at times. They have been subjects of internal investigation
column599: and storms of online abuse. “If they expel me
column600: it will mean that this is no longer the right place for me
column601: ” Nugnes says. But she adds: “There are so many like me in the movement. No one can know the future of the movement.” Many believe that the future of the movement is Alessandro Di Battista. The popular former MP decided not to run for election in 2018
column602: despite being omnipresent during the campaign; he says he wanted to get back to the “real world” outside Parliament for a while. Insiders speculate that the real aim of his political hiatus is to avoid hitting his mandatory two-term limit. Once his ally Di Maio’s time is up
column604: Di Battista will take over the party’s leadership. Of all the movement’s leaders
column605: Di Battista is Five Star’s unabashed Casaleggian radical. On a scratchy WhatsApp line from Guatemala
column606: where he has passed much of his time out of power
column607: Di Battista comes out swinging when I ask about Five Star’s apparent rightward slide: “Today
column608: whoever wants to take back sovereignty is considered a fascist
column614: are just another case of media elites missing the point. “The world can’t be judged from an attic in Manhattan. They don’t understand anything—just as they understood nothing of Trump and Brexit
column615: just as they’ve understood nothing about the Five Star Movement.” For Di Battista
column616: Five Star’s grand techno-utopian project is never far from sight. “Representative democracy is obsolete
column617: ” he tells me. It will soon be as old hat as absolute monarchy seems to us today. “The future is inevitably direct democracy
column618: ” he says. But who knows if that future will be quite as inevitable without a hidden hand to steer it. Darren Loucaides (@DarrenLoucaides) is a British writer who covers politics

column1: ---split---4.0---split---https://www.huffpost.com/entry/supreme-court-census-citizenship-question_n_5c634dd7e4b03de94296978b---split---The U.S. Supreme Court announced on Friday that it would hear an expedited appeal in a case seeking to block the Trump administration from adding a citizenship question to the 2020 census. The justices’ decision to take up the case of Department of Commerce v. New York was largely expected and marks the latest step in a closely watched legal battle over next year’s census. Critics contend that adding the citizenship question would discourage people
column2: particularly people of color
column3: from responding to the survey. An inaccurate census would have drastic consequences
column4: they warn
column5: because its results are used to allocate congressional seats and hundreds of billions of dollars in federal funds. In January
column6: a federal judge in Manhattan blocked the Trump administration from adding the question. Normally
column7: the case would then go to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 2nd Circuit before heading to the Supreme Court. But with the Census Bureau facing a fast-approaching June deadline for finalizing census questions
column8: the high court has agreed to hear argument in the appeal in late April. Both the plaintiffs in the suit ― 18 states
column9: the District of Columbia
column10: several cities and a handful of immigrant rights groups ― and the Trump administration argued in court filings that if the justices were going to take the case
column11: they should do so quickly and bypass the 2nd Circuit. In a 277-page opinion last month
column12: U.S. District Judge Jesse Furman held that the way the Trump administration added the question ran afoul of a federal law called the Administrative Procedure Act. He found that Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross
column13: who oversees the Census Bureau
column14: had ignored analyses from experts on how damaging the question would be and cherry-picked evidence to support his desire to add the question. Ross publicly claimed that he began considering the question only after the Justice Department requested it and that the Justice Department wanted the question in order to obtain better data to enforce the Voting Rights Act. But Furman
column15: who was appointed to the federal bench by then-President Barack Obama
column16: said the voting rights rationale was “pretextual
column17: ” a “sham justification” concealing the true reason for Ross’ decision. The decennial census ― which goes out to every American household ― hasn’t asked about citizenship since the Voting Rights Act was passed in 1965. And a top Justice Department official was unable to explain in a sworn deposition how adding the citizenship question would get the department better citizenship data than it already had available. In total
column18: seven different lawsuits have been filed challenging the addition of the citizenship question. This story has been updated to note that the Supreme Court will hear argument in the case in late April. Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? Here’s how.

column1: ---split---4.0---split---http://www.rollcall.com/news/hoh/don-jr---split---Donald Trump Jr. walks through Statuary Hall toward Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office before realizing his mistake and turning around. Trump Jr. intended to pay a visit to Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy at the Capitol before his father’s State of the Union address. (Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call) Donald Trump Jr. entered Statuary Hall for his father’s State of the Union address on Tuesday headed for a friendly office but ended up in enemy territory. The president’s son intended to pay a visit to the office of Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy but was headed to that of Speaker Nancy Pelosi before he reversed course. Heard on the Hill suspects that route was out of habit for Trump Jr.
column2: given that Paul Ryan inhabited that office when Republicans controlled the House. Democrats took over control of the House in January after winning more seats in the 2018 midterm elections. It’s common for party leadership to have meetings with family members
column3: political figures and State of the Union guests ahead of the address. Watch — SOTU: A brief history Get breaking news alerts and more from Roll Call on your iPhone or your Android. THE SOURCE FOR NEWS ON CAPITOL HILL SINCE 1955 Want insight more often?  Get Roll Call in your inbox  ×

column1: ---split---4.0---split---https://www.wired.com/story/jargon-watch-rising-danger-stochastic-terrorism/---split---n. Acts of violence by random extremists
column2: triggered by political demagoguery. When President Trump tweeted a video of himself body-slamming the CNN logo in 2017
column3: most people took it as a stupid joke. For Cesar Sayoc
column4: it may have been a call to arms: Last October the avowed Trump fan allegedly mailed a pipe bomb to CNN headquarters. No one told Sayoc to do it
column5: but the fact that it happened was really no surprise. In 2011
column6: after the shooting of US representative Gabby Giffords
column7: a Daily Kos blog warned of a new threat the writer called stochastic terrorism: the use of mass media to incite attacks by random nut jobs—acts that are “statistically predictable but individually unpredictable.” The writer had in mind right-wing radio and TV agitators
column8: but in 2016
column9: Rolling Stone accused then-candidate Trump of using the same playbook when he joked that “Second Amendment people” might “do” something if Hillary Clinton won the election. Of course
column10: Trump’s people later said he meant they might … “vote.” That’s how it works: Stochastic terrorism lets bullies operate in the open with full deniability
column11: since the random element erases any provable causation. Tellingly
column12: the word stochastic comes from the Greek stochastikos
column13: meaning “proceeding by guesswork” and “skillful in aiming.” Both are apt here. It takes a master demagogue to weaponize unstable individuals and aim them at political enemies. This article appears in the February issue. Subscribe now. A guide to busting through confirmation bias
column14: the cognitive fallacy that's destroying our discourse. CNMN Collection © 2018 Condé Nast. All rights reserved. column2: Facts and Trends Shaping Your World About Follow  By Abigail Geiger
column3: Kristen Bialik and John Gramlich The 116th U.S. Congress took office in January
column4: with Democrats taking control of the House while Republicans maintain an edge in the Senate. Apart from its political makeup
column5: the new Congress differs from prior ones in other ways
column6: including its demographics. Here are six charts that show how Congress has changed over time
column7: using historical data from CQ Roll Call
column8: the Brookings Institution
column9: the Congressional Research Service and other sources. 1The current Congress is the most racially and ethnically diverse ever. Nonwhites – including blacks
column10: Hispanics
column11: Asians/Pacific Islanders and Native Americans – now account for 22% of Congress
column12: including a quarter of the House and 9% of the Senate. By comparison
column13: when the 79th Congress took office in 1945
column14: nonwhites represented just 1% of the House and Senate. Despite this growing racial and ethnic diversity
column15: Congress still lags the nation as a whole: The share of nonwhites in the United States is nearly double that of the country’s legislative body (39% vs. 22%). Read More → Topics: Congress
column16: Federal Government
column17: Demographics By John Gramlich and Kat Devlin A growing share of people around the world see U.S. power and influence as a “major threat” to their country
column18: and these views are linked with attitudes toward President Donald Trump and the United States as a whole
column19: according to Pew Research Center surveys conducted in 22 nations since 2013. A median of 45% across the surveyed nations see U.S. power and influence as a major threat
column20: up from 38% in the same countries during Trump’s first year as president in 2017 and 25% in 2013
column21: during the administration of Barack Obama. The long-term increase in the share of people who see American power as a threat has occurred alongside declines in the shares of people who say they have confidence in the U.S. president to do the right thing regarding world affairs and who have a favorable view of the United States. (For more about global views toward the U.S. president and the country he leads
column22: see “Trump’s International Ratings Remain Low
column23: Especially Among Key Allies.”) Despite these changes
column24: U.S. power and influence still ranks below other perceived threats around the world. Considerably larger shares of people point to global climate change (seen as a major threat by a median of 67%)
column25: the Islamic militant group known as ISIS (cited by 62%) and cyberattacks (cited by 61%). U.S. power and influence
column26: in fact
column27: is not seen as the top threat in any of the countries surveyed. Read More → Topics: U.S. Global Image and Anti-Americanism
column28: Country Image
column29: Donald Trump By Abigail Geiger and Gretchen Livingston The landscape of relationships in America has shifted dramatically in recent decades. From cohabitation to same-sex marriage to interracial and interethnic marriage
column30: here are eight facts about love and marriage in the United States. 1Half of Americans ages 18 and older were married in 2017
column31: a share that has remained relatively stable in recent years but is down 8 percentage points since 1990. One factor driving this change is that Americans are staying single longer. The median age at first marriage had reached its highest point on record: 30 years for men and 28 years for women in 2018
column32: according to the U.S. Census Bureau. As the U.S. marriage rate has declined
column33: divorce rates have increased among older Americans. In 2015
column34: for every 1
column35: 000 married adults ages 50 and older
column36: 10 had divorced – up from five in 1990. Among those ages 65 and older
column37: the divorce rate roughly tripled since 1990. Read More → Category: 5 Facts Topics: Lifestyle
column38: Family and Relationships
column39: Marriage and Divorce By Aaron Smith Algorithms are all around us
column40: using massive stores of data and complex analytics to make decisions with often significant impacts on humans – from choosing the content people see on social media to judging whether a person is a good credit risk or job candidate. Pew Research Center released several reports in 2018 that explored the role and meaning of algorithms in people’s lives today. Here are some of the key themes that emerged from that research. 1Algorithmically generated content platforms play a prominent role in Americans’ information diets. Sizable shares of U.S. adults now get news on sites like Facebook or YouTube that use algorithms to curate the content they show to their users. A study by the Center found that 81% of YouTube users say they at least occasionally watch the videos suggested by the platform’s recommendation algorithm
column41: and that these recommendations encourage users to watch progressively longer content as they click through the videos suggested by the site. 2The inner workings of even the most common algorithms can be confusing to users. Facebook is among the most popular social media platforms
column42: but roughly half of Facebook users – including six-in-ten users ages 50 and older – say they do not understand how the site’s algorithmically generated news feed selects which posts to show them. And around three-quarters of Facebook users are not aware that the site automatically estimates their interests and preferences based on their online behaviors in order to deliver them targeted advertisements and other content. Read More → Topics: Emerging Technology Impacts
column43: Science and Innovation
column44: Future of the Internet By Christine Tamir Nigeria will be holding presidential and parliamentary elections against a backdrop of negative sentiment in the country about the state of the economy and political system. These attitudes were evident in a Pew Research Center survey conducted in the summer of 2018. Nigeria is home to the largest population in Africa
column45: which is almost evenly split between Muslims and Christians. Incumbent President Muhammadu Buhari of the All Progressives Congress (APC) will be running against multiple candidates including former Vice President Atiku Abubakar of the People’s Democratic Party (PDP)
column46: John Gbor of the All Progressives Grand Alliance (APGA)
column47: Usman Muhammed of the Labour Party (LP) and others. Tensions in the country have grown in the final weeks before elections because of Buhari’s controversial decision to suspend the country’s chief justice. These five charts capture the Nigerian public’s mood about the state of their nation and the differing attitudes of the Muslim and Christian populations. column49: Political Attitudes and Values By Jonathan Evans Germany is the birthplace of Martin Luther and the Protestant Reformation
column50: but since the middle of the 20th century
column51: the country has seen a dramatic shift away from Protestantism – one that has greatly outpaced a decline in the share of Germans who are Catholic. Protestants represented a majority (59%) of Germany’s population in 1950
column52: with Catholics as a sizable minority (37%)
column53: according to research by Detlef Pollack and Olaf Müller
column54: scholars of religion and sociology at the University of Münster in Germany. These shares are largely based on church membership rolls that include both children and adults. Over the next 60 years
column55: the share of Protestants fell 30 percentage points
column56: while the share of Catholics dropped 7 points. Each group now includes roughly three-in-ten Germans
column57: based on 2010 membership data. Declines in the shares of Protestants and Catholics have been accompanied by a rising share of the religiously unaffiliated
column58: who accounted for 30% of Germans in 2010
column59: up from fewer than 4% in 1950. And recent research indicates that the share of Muslims in Germany also has been growing in recent years
column60: due in large part to immigration. Read More → Topics: Western Europe
column64: Europe By David Masci Tuesday is the 210th anniversary of Charles Darwin’s birth
column65: a day now celebrated by some as Darwin Day. Darwin is best known for his theory of evolution through natural selection. When Darwin’s work was first made public in 1859
column66: it shocked Britain’s religious establishment. And while today it is accepted by virtually all scientists
column67: evolutionary theory still is rejected by many Americans
column68: often because it conflicts with their religious beliefs about divine creation. While not an official holiday
column69: Darwin Day has been adopted by scientific and humanist groups to promote everything from scientific literacy to secularism. This year
column70: dozens of events have been planned worldwide
column71: many of them anchored by scientific talks or symposiums. To mark the occasion
column72: here are six facts about the public’s views on evolution
column73: as well as other aspects of the debate in the U.S. and elsewhere: 1Roughly eight-in-ten U.S. adults (81%) say humans have evolved over time
column74: according to data from a new Pew Research Center study. This includes one-third of all Americans (33%) who say that humans evolved due to processes like natural selection with no involvement by God or a higher power
column75: along with 48% who believe human evolution occurred through processes guided or allowed by God or a higher power. The same survey found that 18% of Americans reject evolution entirely
column76: saying humans have always existed in their present form. (See the full report for a deeper look at the ways question wording and format can affect survey results on evolution.) Read More → Category: 5 Facts Topics: Religion and Society
column79: Science and Innovation By Anna Brown A slight majority of Americans (53%) think it is generally unacceptable for a white person to use makeup to darken their skin to appear to be a different race as part of a Halloween costume
column80: including 37% who say this is never acceptable. About one-in-three (34%) say this is always or sometimes acceptable
column81: according to a recent Pew Research Center survey. The survey was conducted almost entirely before news broke about Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam and other high-profile politicians who have been accused of wearing blackface as part of costumes when they were younger. White adults are about twice as likely as black adults to say the use of blackface as part of a Halloween costume can be acceptable: 39% of whites hold this view vs. 19% of blacks. Hispanics fall in the middle
column82: with 28% saying this is always or sometimes acceptable. Among whites
column83: those younger than 30 are far less accepting of the use of blackface. About a quarter of younger whites (27%) say it is at least sometimes acceptable for a white person to use makeup to darken their skin to appear to be a different race as part of a Halloween costume
column84: but about two-thirds say this is rarely (23%) or never (41%) acceptable. Older whites are more divided
column85: with roughly four-in-ten of those ages 30 and older saying this is acceptable at least sometimes
column86: and about half or fewer in each group saying this is rarely or never acceptable. Acceptance of blackface also is more common among whites without a college degree. While 44% of whites with some college or less education say this is always or sometimes acceptable
column87: 28% of whites with at least a bachelor’s degree say the same. Read More → Topics: Race and Ethnicity By Kristen Bialik More than one-in-five voting members (22%) of the U.S. House of Representatives and Senate are racial or ethnic minorities
column88: making the 116th Congress the most racially and ethnically diverse in history. There has been a long-running trend toward more racial and ethnic diversity on Capitol Hill: Each of the previous four Congresses broke the record set by the Congress before it. Overall
column92: according to a Pew Research Center analysis of data from the Congressional Research Service. This represents an 84% increase over the 107th Congress of 2001-03
column93: which had 63 minority members. Although recent Congresses have continued to set new highs for racial and ethnic diversity
column94: they have still been disproportionately white when compared with the overall U.S. population. Nonwhites make up 39% of the nation’s population
column95: according to U.S. Census Bureau population estimates. (For this analysis
column96: Hispanics are included in the Census Bureau estimates for the share of each racial minority group in the overall population.) In the House of Representatives
column98: some racial and ethnic groups are now on par with their share of the total population. For example
column100: about equal to the share of Americans who are black. And Native Americans now make up 1% of the House
column101: equal to their 1% of the population. Other nonwhite groups in the House are somewhat less represented relative to their share of the population. The share of Hispanics in the U.S. population (18%) is twice as high as it is in the House (9%). Asians account for 6% of the national population but 3% of House members. The increase in minority representation in the House has largely come among newly elected Democrats. Of the 22 freshman representatives who are nonwhite
column102: just one is a Republican (Rep. Anthony Gonzalez of Ohio
column103: who is Hispanic). Nine senators are a racial or ethnic minority
column104: unchanged from the 115th Congress. Four senators are Hispanic
column105: three are Asian and three are black. (Kamala Harris
column107: is black and Asian). There are no nonwhite freshman senators. In the full 116th Congress
column108: the overwhelming majority of racial and ethnic nonwhite members are Democrats (90%)
column109: while just 10% are Republicans. Non-Hispanic whites make up 78% of voting members in the new Congress
column110: considerably larger than their 61% share of the U.S. population overall. And despite the growing racial and ethnic diversity of Congress
column111: this gap has widened over time: In 1981
column113: compared with 80% of the U.S. population. This analysis includes a few members who are counted under more than one racial or ethnic identity. In addition to Harris
column116: is counted as both black and Asian. Reps. Antonio Delgado and Adriano Espaillat
column118: are listed as black and Hispanic. Espaillat
column119: the first Dominican American elected to Congress
column120: self-identifies as a Latino of African descent. Portuguese American members are not included in the Hispanic count. In addition
column121: one disputed seat in the House – North Carolina’s 9th District – is not included in the total number of voting seats. Note: For analyses of previous Congresses

column123: ethnic diversity 114th Congress is the most diverse ever Topics: Congress
column125: Race and Ethnicity By Haley Davie and Baxter Oliphant The share of Americans who say stricter environmental laws and regulations are “worth the cost” has ticked up in recent years
column126: with a significant shift coming among Republicans. Today
column127: 63% of U.S. adults say stricter environmental regulations are “worth the cost
column128: ” while 30% say such regulations “cost too many jobs and hurt the economy
column129: ” according to a new survey by Pew Research Center. Two years ago
column130: the balance of opinion was narrower
column131: as 59% said stricter environmental regulations were worth the cost
column132: while 37% said they cost too many jobs. Partisanship continues to be a major factor in opinions about tougher environmental laws
column133: with Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents far more likely than Republicans and GOP leaners to view stricter laws and regulations as worth the cost. But since 2017
column134: the share of Republicans who take a positive view of stricter environmental laws has increased
column135: from 36% then to 45% today. There has been little change in Democrats’ views in this period (77% then
column137: Republicans remain less supportive of stricter environmental laws and regulations than they were during the 1990s and much of the 2000s. In 2007
column139: 58% of Republicans said they were worth the cost. Read More → Topics: Energy and Environment

column6: Kirsten Gillibrand of New York

column15: which Democrats oppose and have threatened to challenge in court. Candidates who opposed the bill spoke out against the emergency declaration
column16: with many referring to the wall as Trump’s “vanity project.” “The President is going to abuse his power with a non-credible national emergency to go around Congress and waste taxpayer dollars for an ineffective border wall
column17: ” Gillibrand said in a statement Thursday evening. She specifically cited the spending measure’s increased funding for the Immigration and Custom Enforcement agency
column18: saying “it comes with no accountability and will give the President the ability to continue his inhumane policies.” Booker offered a similar reasoning for his ‘no’ vote: “This funding bill gives ICE and [Customs and Border Protection] hundreds of millions of additional dollars with little oversight or appropriate guardrails.” Harris voted against the bill out of concern about the increase in funding for the Department of Homeland Security and potential increased capacity for detention facilities. Sanders said he had reservations about the legislation but ultimately supported it because of the federal workers affected by the last shutdown. “I cannot turn my back on the two million federal employees and private contract workers who would be forced
column19: again

column2: D-Calif.
column3: conducts her weekly news conference Thursday in which she fielded questions about the government funding bill. (Tom Williams/CQ Roll Call) The House passed a spending package Thursday night
column4: completing congressional action to avert a government shutdown with barely a day to spare. The final vote was 300-128. Nineteen Democrats voted against the measure
column5: while 109 Republicans
column6: representing a majority of their conference
column7: were opposed. Earlier in the day
column8: the Senate passed the $333 billion fiscal 2019 package by an 83-16 vote. It contains seven of the 12 annual appropriations bills that were not signed into law before the Oct. 1 start of the fiscal year. The four-and-a-half month delay in completing the fiscal 2019 appropriations process arose over an impasse over the Homeland Security bill — in particular President Donald Trump’s request for $5.7 billion in funding for a border wall. After a 35-day partial government shutdown over that issue that stretched from late December to late January
column9: a House-Senate conference committee was formed to negotiate the final details on border security spending. The 17 appropriators on the conference committee narrowed in on a solution
column10: before the top four appropriators from both chambers reached an agreement in principle Monday night. The final package provides just under $1.4 billion for a physical border barrier. Trump’s frustration with that figure is why he has decided to declare a national emergency to give himself the flexibility to divert other funds for construction of a barrier. “President Trump will sign the government funding bill
column11: and as he has stated before
column12: he will also take other executive action — including a national emergency — to ensure we stop the national security and humanitarian crisis at the border
column13: ” White House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said in a statement. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said Trump will declare the national emergency when he signs the spending package
column14: which is expected to be Friday given that’s the final day to prevent the government from shutting down again. The Kentucky Republican said he will support Trump’s emergency declaration
column15: but Speaker Nancy Pelosi and her Democratic Caucus are opposed. The California Democrat called it “an end-run” around Congress that should alarm Republicans too. “It is interesting to see how the president has said to the Republican leadership in the Senate ... ‘I don’t have confidence in what you did
column16: ’ even though the president failed to convince the American people and their representatives in Congress of his position

column1: ---split---6.0---split---https://www.huffpost.com/entry/mike-pence-berlin-trump_n_5c6873dce4b033a799432eb6---split---Vice President Mike Pence appeared to have overestimated his audience’s opinion of the American president on Friday when he spoke during an event at the Munich Security Conference. The vice president was in Germany as part of a delegation of U.S. lawmakers to the annual conference that dates back to the height of the Cold War. ″I especially want to invite all of you to thank Senator Lindsey Graham for leading this delegation
column2: ” Pence said. A strong round of applause followed. “And to [...] all of you I bring greetings from a great champion of freedom and of strong national defense
column3: who must work with these members of Congress to strengthen America’s military might and strengthen the leadership of the free world
column4: ” he continued. “I bring greetings from the 45th president of the United States of America
column5: President Donald Trump.” The crowd did not react. Pence then paused for several long seconds before continuing his planned remarks. He was speaking at the conference’s inaugural John McCain Dissertation Award ceremony
column6: an academic prize named in honor of the late senator who attended the meeting for decades ― and who was famously antagonized by Trump. Addressing U.S. allies at the Munich Security Conference
column7: Mike Pence is met with silence as he tells the audience: "I bring greetings from the 45th president of the United States of America
column8: President Donald Trump." pic.twitter.com/yr7SNVhCVf The Trump administration is not popular among the conference’s global leaders and defense chiefs. A report put out ahead of the conference decried the administration’s “irritating enthusiasm for strongmen across the globe” and “disdain for international institutions and agreements.” “The whole liberal world order appears to be falling apart ― nothing is as it once was
column9: ” Wolfgang Ischinger
column10: chairman of the Munich Security Conference
column11: wrote in an editorial published ahead of the conference. When German Chancellor Angela Merkel finished an extended critique of Trump’s “America First” policies

column13: an adviser to the president and his eldest daughter

column9: arrived in Northern Mexico in late November as part of a caravan that originated in Honduras. Since then
column10: more than 1
column11: 000 have accepted an offer to be returned home by the Mexican government
column12: the officials said. Another 1
column13: 000 have decided to stay in Mexico
column14: accepting work permits that were offered to them last fall
column15: at the height of international consternation over how to deal with the growing presence of migrant caravans. Mr. Trump resorted on Friday to declaring a national emergency after he failed to secure funding from Congress for a border wall that he said would block migrants from entering the United States. But the data from Mexican officials suggested that harsh policies he has introduced to crack down on asylum seekers may already be achieving some of its intended effects. Added this week to new policies that are bearing down on asylum seekers — which include tight limits on the number of people who can apply for the status each day and a heightened standard of proof to qualify — was the extension of a rule that certain asylum seekers must wait in Mexico for the full duration of their legal cases
column16: which can take years. The requirement originally applied only to adults
column17: but the Department of Homeland Security expanded it to include families with children as well. Among those who have been dissuaded
column18: at least for now
column19: is Natali
column21: who asked to be identified only by her first name because she feared for her safety. Speaking from her modest apartment atop a steep hill in western Tijuana
column22: she explained that she and her husband had fled their home in El Progreso
column23: Honduras
column24: after she witnessed a murder carried out by a local criminal gang. Soon after
column25: she began to receive threats in the mail warning her to keep quiet. Once in Mexico
column26: they heard about the increasingly long odds of receiving asylum in the United States
column27: and feared more than anything that officials there would return them to their home country. Rather than crossing the border
column28: they decided to seek humanitarian visas to remain in Mexico legally for at least one year
column29: and have slowly begun to build a life. She still believes she might ask for asylum in the United States
column30: but is realistic about her chances. “I like Tijuana
column31: ” she said. “It’s a very pretty city and there’s a lot of work.” More than anything
column32: she fears the United States would deport her back to Honduras. Mexican officials said the data on people who have deferred or given up their quest for asylum in the United States reinforced an idea that is often raised by Mr. Trump: that many caravan members are not truly desperate for protection. “What happened is that many people came on an adventure
column33: trying their luck
column34: ” said Cesar Palencia
column35: Tijuana’s chief of migrant services. “When they realized that it was hard to cross and the conditions in Mexico were also difficult
column36: among many factors
column37: they decided to return home.” The Honduran caravan ballooned in size as it swept through impoverished villages
column38: drawing a swarm of national media attention and an eclectic mix of participants. Many came from poverty
column39: lacking education and resources
column40: and said they were unfamiliar with the complex set of laws that would ultimately determine who would be granted legal status in the United States
column41: and who would not. Immigrant advocates said that hype and false promises had attracted a group that was somewhat unrepresentative of typical asylum seekers. But they pointed to the roughly 4
column42: 000 members who had successfully entered the United States and had at least requested protected status to argue that most had legitimate claims. Michelle Brané
column43: the director of migrant rights and justice at the Women’s Refugee Commission
column44: warned that while Mr. Trump’s tough policies may discourage the undeserving
column45: they might also endanger people who need protection. She said they would likely drive vulnerable migrants into the arms of human traffickers
column46: who promise to provide passage into the United States. “It may look like it’s working in the short term
column47: ” Ms. Brané said
column48: “But I don’t think it’s a long-term solution. It’s driving people further into the shadows and that’s exactly the opposite of what we want.” When they arrived in Mexico
column49: many of the caravan members had been living in squalor
column50: sleeping in tents or lean-tos inside the Benito Juárez sports complex. A downpour devastated the grounds
column51: and those who remained fled to a new expansive shelter called Barretal on the outskirts of Tijuana. Once packed with 2
column52: 500 people
column53: that location also recently closed because it had shrunk to fewer than 200. “It is not the same as when we had Barretal and Benito Juárez
column54: ” said Esme Flores
column55: an immigrant-rights advocate at the San Diego office of the American Civil Liberties Union. “It really feels that the population has moved on.” On Friday
column56: all that remained of the formerly bustling migrant quarter around the Barretal shelter was a small camp around the corner
column57: only partially covered by a tin roof. The conditions are far from comfortable
column58: but the occupants said it was better than sleeping on sidewalks. Most were not yet ready to give up trying to enter the United States
column59: but knew of others who had. Elde Rodriguez
column61: said he had left Honduras hoping to send money back to his wife and daughter. Believing that he would not qualify for asylum
column62: he tried last week to cross the border illegally but he and a friend were unable to find their away across and turned back. “There’s enough work here in Mexico
column63: and you can live on that if you’re alone. But you can’t make enough to send money home
column64: and that’s the point about all this
column65: ” he said. “If I can’t get in
column66: I’ll just keep trying.” While Tijuana appears to be emptying
column67: large groups of migrants have accumulated in other areas along the border as a result of the new policies. After a riot the day before
column68: authorities in Mexico said on Friday that they would disband a group of 1
column69: 400 Central American asylum seekers who had been waiting in the city of Piedras Negras to cross the border into Eagle Pass
column71: according to news reports. The Trump administration has said that the latest policy requiring asylum seekers to wait in Mexico
column72: which it called Migrant Protection Protocols
column73: is a vital response to a crisis at the border. Kirstjen Nielsen
column74: secretary of the Department of Homeland Security
column75: has said the policy aims to alleviate a humanitarian crisis on the border and secure the United States. Introduced as a pilot program across the border from San Diego
column76: the administration plans to expand the policy into Texas. Border Patrol apprehensions of families along the southwest border remain near all-time highs
column77: though there was a slight downward turn in January
column79: according the latest government figures. Customs and Border Protection said more than 1
column80: 800 Central American parents and children crossed the border illegally on Monday
column81: the largest number of families recorded on a single day. And like other asylum policies of this administration

column83: leaving its future uncertain. On Thursday

column86: which was introduced last month at the San Ysidro port of entry
column88: violates United States and international laws. The lawsuit was filed in federal court in the Northern District of California on behalf of migrants from Guatemala

column90: according to the complaint. One of them was robbed at gunpoint and told by the assailant that he would be killed if he was seen again. column104: ” she said. “I’ve dreamed of doing this my entire life but I was afraid. Hiding through the desert and the mountains

column107: yes” she would cross illegally if that is what it takes to get into the United States. But if she is unable to gain entry to the United States

column110: what else can you do in that case?”    Advertisement

column1: ---split---7.0---split---https://www.huffpost.com/entry/tax-refunds-gop-law_n_5c671dcee4b033a799429900---split---Republicans boasted all last year that their new tax law boosted paychecks and showered bonuses on several million workers. But now that tax season is upon us
column2: several million Americans are getting a nasty surprise: a bill from the Internal Revenue Service that they never expected. Beth Callori of Long Island
column3: New York
column4: said she was thrilled to receive about $90 more in each paycheck last year. Thanks to the new lower federal income tax rates
column5: Callori’s employer
column6: a financial services firm
column7: was withholding less from her paycheck for federal tax purposes. “I thought
column8: ‘Wow
column9: Trump is great
column10: I love him
column11: ’” Callori said. But last week Callori heard from her tax preparer that she owes the federal government more than $5
column12: 000 ― almost five times as much as she had to pay in previous years. “I almost fell out of my chair. I could not believe it
column13: ” she said. “I voted for Trump. I thought he was going to be good for this country
column14: but when I got that phone call
column15: that’s it
column16: I’m done.” Callori’s tax bill went up for two reasons. One is that the law directly disadvantaged her by limiting deductions for state and local taxes
column17: which increased the amount of Callori’s income subject to tax and added an extra grand to her bill. The bigger reason is that her employer withheld too little from her paycheck. The extra $90 she received should have been added to the amount that gets automatically socked away to cover the federal income tax. Like most people
column18: however
column19: Callori did not fill out a worksheet and submit a new Form W-4 to her employer at the beginning of last year. After all
column20: at that time Republicans kept bragging about the bigger paychecks they had given the American people. “I thought because I was getting that
column21: I’m entitled to it
column22: ” Callori said. The vast majority of Americans got lower taxes from the new law
column23: while only 5 percent or so should have seen a tax increase. Most people should have seen the changes in their paychecks last February. But the way the Trump administration implemented the law has caused a separate problem ― one that the administration knew would result in something like 5 million fewer households receiving tax refunds this year. It’s still early in tax filing season
column24: which opened at the end of January
column25: but the average refund is down 8.7 percent so far. The Treasury Department suggested tax refunds are bad anyway because they result from people overpaying the government. “Smaller refunds mean that people are withholding appropriately based on their tax liability
column26: which is positive news for taxpayers
column27: ” a spokesperson said in an email. The problem is
column28: it’s not just smaller refunds ― it’s that paycheck withholding for this tax season is less accurate in general. Treasury has said it expected the percentage of people withholding too much tax in their paychecks to decline from 76 to 73 percent
column29: but the percentage withholding accurately is not increasing at all. Instead
column30: Treasury expected the rate of under-withholding to go from 18 to 21 percent. Those people all owe the IRS. The households most at risk are ones with higher incomes
column31: two earners and slightly more complicated taxes ― especially households that used to itemize their deductions. Instead of taking the standard deduction
column32: which reduces taxable income by a set value
column33: itemizers would add up what they spent on state and local taxes
column34: mortgage interest and charitable giving
column35: and deduct that sum instead. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act greatly reduced the advantage of itemizing and limited the deduction for state and local tax. But the Trump administration decided not to make major changes to the withholding tables that employers are required to use to make sure everybody is paying the right amount of tax. The value of “allowances” that workers can choose on Form W-4 to adjust their withholding has been pegged for years to something called the personal exemption ― which the new tax law eliminated. So they set the value of allowances to last year’s personal exemption and adjusted for inflation. Coming up with new forms would have taken at least half a year
column36: and would have been a chore for everyone. “There’s this tension … You’d like to get all the information needed to calculate withholding as accurately as possible
column37: but that gets very complicated for taxpayers
column38: ” said Joe Rosenberg
column39: a researcher at the Tax Policy Center. The administration could have let people withhold too much rather than surprise them with bills at tax time
column40: Democrats have said. “It looks like the Trump Treasury Department spent 2018
column41: an election year
column42: goosing people’s paychecks by under-withholding
column43: and it should have been obvious that the bill would come due eventually
column44: ” Sen. Ron Wyden (D-Ore.) said in a statement Friday. The IRS did try to warn people to check their withholding. The agency told the Government Accountability Office that it put out press releases and sent emails to listservs with hundreds of thousands of subscribers. It promoted a “paycheck checkup” campaign on Twitter and Facebook
column45: and officials talked to the media. The “make sure you’re not underwithheld” messaging may have been drowned out by congressional Republicans bragging that their law had turbocharged the economy and directly benefited millions of workers. They kept a running tally of the hundreds of firms that had announced bonuses for their employees
column46: trumpeting each announcement in a series of press releases. Fox News worked overtime to remind people that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi previously called the bonuses “crumbs
column47: ” as though that weren’t a perfectly accurate description. Another problem
column48: which is not Republicans’ fault
column49: is that even though everyone pays taxes
column50: not everyone understands them very well. Less than half of Americans said they knew they could update their W-4 forms at any time and only 19 percent had actually done so
column51: according to a November survey by the tax prep company H&R Block. Twice as many survey respondents said they updated their W-2
column52: which is actually a document prepared by employers
column53: not workers. Also
column54: some filers are surprised by tax bills simply because they didn’t realize some of the money they earned needed to be taxed. “They’ll have some side job where there’s no withholding and that’s creating this new tax liability
column55: ” H&R Block’s Nathan Rigney said
column56: pointing to the rise of non-employee gigs like Uber and Taskrabbit. By capping deductions for state and local taxes
column57: Republicans knew the tax hikes in their law would be concentrated on states with high taxes ― which tend to be led by Democrats
column58: who use the taxes to provide more social services. But it’s not just wealthy New Yorkers who’ve wound up paying more. Kurt Kromm is an electrician in Kenosha
column59: Wisconsin ― an area that used to be represented by former House Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.). Kromm knew he and his wife would pay higher taxes because of the limit on deductions for state and local taxes
column60: but he didn’t think they would owe more than $4
column61: 000 this spring. Kromm had already indicated on the Form W-4 documents he’d previously submitted to his employer that he was married and wanted zero allowances
column62: which means he was withholding as much as he could without specifying an additional dollar amount. “I figured married and zero would probably be appropriate
column63: ” Kromm said. “They spent no time trying to really put out a decent withholding table.” Kromm’s case shows the two-earner household pitfall. After he realized how much he owes
column64: he went to the withholding calculator on IRS.gov and realized he could have either told his employer to take an additional $80 per week or just chosen to withhold at a single rate on his W-4
column65: since single people face higher rates and therefore higher withholding. If he had done so last year
column66: he could have had less money in each paycheck but saved himself the aggravation of making a large payment. But not even the administration expected people to go to such lengths ― in its simulations of how people would be affected
column67: the IRS assumed nobody would adjust their W-4s. “It’s unreasonable to expect working people with busy lives to start the year out by crunching the numbers on their tax withholding with the rigor of a workaholic [certified public accountant]
column70: said she had also previously chosen zero allowances ― plus she had an extra $130 withheld from each paycheck. It wasn’t enough. She said she used to love Donald Trump. Not anymore. “I really liked things he was doing
column73: ” she said. Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? Here’s how.

(Lintao Zhang/Getty Images file photo) The White House on Friday said “intensive” trade talks this week with Chinese officials yielded “progress
column3: ” but there was no indication President Donald Trump is ready to delay a substantial ballooning of tariffs on Chinese-made goods set to take effect March 1. “These detailed and intensive discussions led to progress between the two parties
column4: ” press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders said in a statement. “Much work remains
column5: however.” The latter assessment reflects what top White House officials have said for months: on major issues like Chinese government subsidies to its firms
column6: U.S. companies’ intellectual property rights and a handful of others
column7: Beijing has never budged months during nearly two years of high-level talks. [Trump’s executive order will tap $6.6. billion in Pentagon
column8: Treasury funds for wall
column9: source says] This week’s round of talks in China
column10: like others have focused on those issues and others like forced technology transfers demanded of U.S. companies
column11: forced joint ventures
column12: non-tariff barriers on agricultural and industrial goods
column13: and cybersecurity matters. “It’s the same list
column14: ” a clearly frustrated White House chief economic adviser Lawrence Kudlow told reporters in late November. “We haven’t seen much change.” Since
column15: Kudlow and others have promised reporters new rounds of talks have yielded “progress
column16: ” but they decline to provide specifics. That language was back Friday
column17: with the top White House spokeswoman saying “the United States looks forward to these further talks and hopes to see additional progress
column18: ” referring to a new round next week in Washington. Trump earlier this week said he would consider pushing back a deadline in just 14 days at which time U.S. tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese-made goods will swell from 10 percent to 25 percent if he thinks talks are moving toward a deal. But Sanders gave no indication Friday that he is ready to make that move
column19: a sign he sees it as leverage for his team of negotiators. [Legal fight expected for Trump’s national emergency declaration] “Both sides will continue working on all outstanding issues in advance of the March 1
column21: deadline for an increase in the 10 percent tariff on certain imported Chinese goods
column22: ” Sanders said. Lawmakers have both applauded the Trump administration for its tough stance on China’s trade practices and urged the president to resist an all-out trade war that could drive the American and global economies into a recession. Report language in the spending package Trump is slated to sign Friday morning tells the U.S. Trade Representative’s Office it “shall” create a process for businesses to seek tariff exemptions for imported products affected by U.S. duties on $200 billion in Chinese goods. The agency has said it would create an exemption process if U.S.-China trade talks fail
column23: prompting the tariffs to increase to 25 percent. White House officials said earlier this month that any U.S.-China trade pact would not be required to get congressional approval
column24: but they said they are keeping key lawmakers updated on the talks. Trump campaigned on getting tougher on Beijing in 2016
column25: and brings it up at his political rallies as he gears up for a re-election fight. Ellyn Ferguson contributed to this report. column1: ---split---8.0---split---https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/15/opinion/trump-border-wall-national-emergency.html---split---Supported by The president plans to manage the border crisis from the golf course at Mar-a-Lago this weekend. By The Editorial Board The editorial board represents the opinions of the board
column2: its editor and the publisher. It is separate from the newsroom and the Op-Ed section. “I didn’t need to do this
column3: ” President Trump insisted at a Rose Garden appearance on Friday
column4: as he declared a national emergency aimed at shaking loose a few billion dollars in financing for his beloved border wall. The president’s assertion was both ludicrous and self-defeating. If a declaration was unnecessary and the wall on track (the wall is “very very on its way
column5: ” the president said earlier in the week)
column6: how could he claim to be addressing an emergency? As Mr. Trump explained it
column7: “But I’d rather do it much faster.” A presidential desire for speed does not constitute a crisis — no matter how eager a president is to camouflage his failures. In reality
column8: the wall is not a done deal
column9: and Mr. Trump has spent the past few months — the past two years
column10: really — failing to convince either Congress or Mexico to pay for it. This week’s bipartisan spending bill
column11: which contained no more wall money than the one over which Mr. Trump shut down the government in December
column12: was a particularly humiliating defeat. Desperate to save face
column13: the president and his team cooked up a nonemergency emergency with the aim of seizing funds already appropriated for other purposes. Currently
column14: the plan is to pull $2.5 billion from the military’s drug interdiction program
column15: $3.6 billion from its construction budget and $600 million from the Treasury Department’s drug forfeiture fund. The White House plans to “backfill” the money it is taking from the Pentagon in future budgets. And so
column16: in a breathtaking display of executive disregard for the separation of powers
column17: the White House is thumbing its nose at Congress
column18: the Constitution and the will of the American people
column19: the majority of whom oppose a border wall. Even as he spun this as an act of strong leadership
column20: Mr. Trump acknowledged that his declaration resolves nothing and creates a host of legal
column21: legislative and political troubles. He predicted that the move would prompt swift legal pushback
column22: which it did. Less than four hours after the announcement
column23: a government watchdog group filed suit
column24: demanding that the Department of Justice hand over “documents concerning the legal authority of the president to invoke emergency powers.” Soon after
column25: the State of California announced its intention to sue. On Thursday
column26: even before the announcement
column27: Protect Democracy and the Niskanen Center announced plans to file on behalf of El Paso County and the Border Network for Human Rights. So the floodgates are open. Mr. Trump predicted that he would lose the first couple of court rounds
column28: particularly in California federal courts
column29: but would ultimately be vindicated by the Supreme Court. Critics of the move expect things to turn out differently. Whatever the outcome
column30: the legal issues are complex
column31: and the case could wind up bogged down indefinitely
column32: meaning not much wall for now. Moving from the legal to the political realm
column33: Republican lawmakers will very likely to find themselves in a pickle. Congress has the power to override a national emergency declaration by passing a joint resolution. To prevent opponents from stalling the bill indefinitely
column34: once one chamber passes the resolution
column35: the other must hold a vote on it within 18 calendar days. House Democrats have already announced their intention to hold such a vote
column36: and are expected to prevail. This will then put Senate Republicans in the position of having to vote on whether to support a presidential grab of Congress’s power. To survive a presidential veto
column37: such a measure would need to pass with two thirds of the votes in both chambers — which seems unlikely. But the vote itself will prove awkward for Republicans
column38: forcing them to go on record as to whether they have officially abandoned their constitutional duties. Then there’s the violence this will do the budget process — not exactly a smooth-running machine as is. But if members of Congress start worrying that money appropriated for one purpose will be clawed back by the White House and handed over for a different one
column39: look for spending battles to get bloodier still. Some of the money to be raided for the wall will come from military construction projects in Republican states like Kentucky and North Carolina. Which brings us to the question of precedent. In defending his declaration
column40: Mr. Trump and his team keep asserting that emergency declarations are not unusual. The president called them “a great thing” that other presidents have done “many
column41: many times.” Since 1976
column42: such declarations have been used 59 times. But most have been uncontroversial and involved matters of foreign policy. Declaring an emergency simply because Congress refused to fund the president’s pet project is seen even by members of his own party as setting a dangerous precedent. As Senator Susan Collins
column43: the Maine Republican
column44: warned
column45: “For the president to use it to repurpose billions of dollars that Congress has appropriated for other purposes and that he has previously signed into law
column46: strikes me as undermining the appropriations process
column47: the vote of Congress and being of dubious constitutionality.” Speaker Nancy Pelosi raised broader issues on Friday. “This issue transcends partisan politics and goes to the core of the Founders’ conception for America
column48: which commands Congress to limit an overreaching executive
column49: ” she said in a statement with Chuck Schumer
column50: the Senate Democratic leader. “The president’s emergency declaration
column51: if unchecked
column52: would fundamentally alter the balance of powers
column53: inconsistent with our Founders’ vision.” “We call upon our Republican colleagues to join us to defend the Constitution
column54: ” they added. “The Congress cannot let the president shred the Constitution.” Mr. Trump betrays no interest in the collateral damage wreaked by his actions. This move will come back to bite him and his party. The question is when
column55: and how hard. The Times is committed to publishing a diversity of letters to the editor. We’d like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles. Here are some tips. And here’s our email: letters@nytimes.com. Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook
column56: Twitter (@NYTopinion) and Instagram. Advertisement

Schumer promise that Democrats in Congress — hopefully joined by some Republicans — will push back against President Donald Trump’s national emergency declaration in multiple arenas. “The President’s actions clearly violate the Congress’ exclusive power of the purse
column7: which our founders enshrined in the Constitution
column8: ” the duo said in a joint statement Friday. “The Congress will defend our constitutional authorities in the Congress
column9: in the courts
column10: and in the public
column11: using every remedy available.” Pelosi and Schumer did not provide specifics regarding the actions they’ll take. But there’s already talk of the House passing a resolution of disapproval
column12: rejecting the emergency declaration. Under the National Emergencies Act of 1976
column13: presidents can take extraordinary actions in times of crisis by declaring a national emergency. A joint resolution disapproving of action under the 1976 law would be considered “privileged” and can be passed with a simple majority vote in each chamber. The privileged status of such a resolution would allow Senate Democrats to force a floor vote over objections of Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell
column14: who said Thursday he supports Trump’s decision. During a Rose Garden announcement Friday
column15: Trump said he would sign a national emergency declaration stating there’s a crisis at the southern border. He plans to shift $3.5 billion from the Defense Department’s military construction fund to the border barrier project. “The President’s unlawful declaration over a crisis that does not exist does great violence to our Constitution and makes America less safe
column16: stealing from urgently needed defense funds for the security of our military and our nation
column17: ” Pelosi and Schumer said. “This is plainly a power grab by a disappointed President
column18: who has gone outside the bounds of the law to try to get what he failed to achieve in the constitutional legislative process.” The Democratic leaders’ promise that Congress will respond in the courts comes as no surprise to the administration. Trump said Friday he expects to get sued and even to get an initial “bad ruling
column19: ” but he expressed confidence the Supreme Court will uphold his declaration. Democrats are likely to coordinate legal action with states and local governments — and potentially
column20: outside interest groups —that will want to sue Trump over the declaration. “The president’s emergency declaration
column21: if unchecked
column22: would fundamentally alter the balance of powers
column23: inconsistent with our founders’ vision
column24: ” Pelosi and Schumer said. Some Republicans have said they do not support Trump using an emergency declaration to go around Congress. But it’s unclear whether they feel strongly enough to get involved in any court action
column25: or to support a resolution of disapproval. Pelosi and Schumer are hoping they will
column26: saying
column27: “We call upon our Republican colleagues to join us to defend the Constitution. Just as both parties honored our oath to protect the American people by passing the conference committee bill
column28: the Congress on a bipartisan basis must honor the Constitution by defending our system of checks and balances.” The Democratic leaders’ statement focused on Trump’s national emergency declaration. It was not immediately clear if they will also seek to challenge his authority to use other executive actions to shift additional money toward the border barrier project. The Trump administration is planning actions that would divert $2.5 billion from the Pentagon’s drug interdiction initiative and $600 million from a Treasury Department drug forfeiture program. White House officials said Friday those funds will “back-filled” in Trump’s fiscal 2020 budget request. John T. Bennett
